summary: Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham player came on as a late substitute in a 0-0 draw against Burnley. Merson had previously criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, but later admitted he was wrong after Townsend scored against Italy. Despite this, Merson couldn't resist another jab at Townsend on Twitter following the Tottenham match.

Chelsea have made a formal offer to FC Tokyo for 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, who would be the first Japanese player to represent the club if he joins. Muto, who has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo, would join Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season as part of the deal. Chelsea's interest in Muto is not linked to their £200million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. Muto, who has 11 international caps and one goal for Japan, is considering the move but has not yet decided. He graduated from Keio University with an economics degree two weeks ago.

The passage discusses a study that found a link between the use of antibiotics in babies during their first six months and an increased likelihood of those babies being overweight by the time they are toddlers. The study, conducted by Finnish researchers and published in the journal Pediatrics, suggests that antibiotics may contribute to weight gain in children similarly to how they are used to fatten farm animals. The researchers emphasize the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy due to the potential impact on childhood obesity rates, which are notably higher among boys. The study does not prove causation but highlights a correlation between antibiotic use and weight gain, suggesting that the alteration of gut bacteria by antibiotics could lead to increased food absorption and appetite. The article also references the broader concern about the overuse of antibiotics leading to antibiotic resistance and the emergence of superbugs.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident was caught on camera and shows the guard losing his footing, sliding sideways, knocking his bearskin on the side of the sentry box, and dropping his rifle. He quickly got back up, but was visibly embarrassed as he noticed the crowd. The guard's mishap occurred last week and was recorded by tourist David Meadwell from Newcastle-upon-Tyne. The guard's fall is believed to have been caused by the metal protectors on the soles of his boots.

"Roots," the iconic miniseries about an African-American slave and his descendants, is being remade by A&E, Lifetime, and History channels for a 2016 release. The new version aims to be original and contemporary, drawing more from Alex Haley's novel and consulting scholars for authenticity. LeVar Burton, who originally played Kunta Kinte, will co-executive produce. The remake is set to reach a new generation of viewers, including those who have witnessed significant racial and political milestones in recent years.

The passage describes an incident in 1978 where a former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claims he was sexually assaulted by palace aides at Clarence House, the London residence of the Queen Mother. Lawler alleges that on his first day, he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member. He left the job immediately after the incident. Lawler says he was ignored when he tried to report the abuse initially but eventually contacted the palace again after inquiries into historical child sex abuse cases. The police are now investigating the claims, which involve a retired royal aide who denies involvement due to being in Balmoral at the time. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate fully with any police investigation.

An Oregon couple announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme song of 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'. The video, featuring Jesse and Melissa Meek, has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. Melissa raps about their family's excitement and pressure to have children, while Jesse mentions their quick conception success after only two months of trying. The couple shares a sonogram of their unborn child at the end of the video. The video was made to inform distant loved ones about the pregnancy and has received unexpected attention.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh in her role as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at auction. The dress, a gray jacket and full skirt ensemble with a black zigzag applique, was worn in several key scenes, including encounters with Rhett Butler and the shanty town attack. The outfit has faded from its original slate blue-gray to light gray over time. The dress was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film, amassed by James Tumblin, who worked in the hair and makeup department at Universal Studios. Tumblin acquired the dress for $20 after finding it about to be discarded. Other notable items from the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh, trousers and jacket worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland as Melanie Wilkes. The auction celebrated the 75th anniversary of the film, which was based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo when he slipped from his mother's arms. The mother was holding him and another child when the toddler fell 10 to 12 feet into the pit. The boy was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived and was taken to the hospital with minor injuries. The cheetahs did not approach the boy, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the mother for allegedly dangling the child over the edge. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera that has been non-functional for over two years due to outdated technology was recently found pointing at a house in Handsworth, Birmingham, West Midlands. Birmingham City Council is aware of the situation and plans to have an engineer visit the site to potentially remove the camera. The council has decommissioned fixed location safety cameras since 2013 and is currently developing a pilot program using digital technology. The camera in Wellington Road will not be part of this new pilot.

Usain Bolt will compete in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas next month as part of the Jamaican team. He is excited to join the relay championship on May 2 and 3, stating he is fit and ready to run. Bolt mentions the event is known for its fun atmosphere and Jamaica's strong relay tradition, expressing his commitment to making the country proud while wearing the national colors. The Jamaican Athletics Administrative Association is pleased Bolt is available for selection, expecting 'sprint magic' from him during the competition. The full Jamaican team list will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves, Barcelona football players, attended a basketball game between Barcelona and Real Madrid, where Barcelona won 85-80. Despite this win, Real Madrid leads the Euro League division by a point difference. Neymar, who captained Brazil to a 1-0 win against Chile at the Emirates Stadium on Sunday, was involved in a physical match. Barcelona leads La Liga by four points after their recent El Clasico victory. Neymar and his team-mates return to La Liga action on Sunday against Celta Vigo as they aim for a treble of trophies.

The passage discusses a surge in the number of migrants attempting to reach Italy from Africa and the Middle East, with a focus on the Mediterranean Sea as the crossing point. It mentions that from Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued, and on Tuesday, there was concern over the potential loss of 400 migrants from a capsized boat. However, the Italian coast guard could not confirm such an incident and found no evidence of a capsized boat with 550 people. The International Organization for Migration (IOM) reported that over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with many rescued at sea. The passage also highlights the dangers of the journey, noting that at least 480 migrants have died this year due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels operated by smugglers.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool. Sanchez, 26, has scored 19 goals since joining Arsenal from Barcelona last summer. Wenger believes Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been linked to their negotiations over Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. The Arsenal boss has played down speculation linking his club with Liverpool winger Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The four-time Olympic champion, who is 35, will try to add to his accomplishments by riding the furthest distance in 60 minutes. The current record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins will hope for a sell-out crowd and his attempt will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. He will prepare for the Hour after racing in the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire and aiming for an eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Games.

Serena Williams, the twice French Open champion, faced a tough match against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup on Sunday, ultimately winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3. Despite her victory, Williams expressed that the match was a "real eye-opener" and revealed her struggle with the clay court conditions, feeling unprepared for the clay season. She acknowledged her hard court mindset was not suitable for the clay and mentioned the need to hit a thousand shots to adapt. The US team lost the play-off 3-2, with Williams and Alison Riske being defeated in doubles by Errani and Flavia Pennetta. The defeat relegated the US to World Group II. Mary Joe Fernandez, the US captain, expressed optimism for future success, noting the team's depth with several players in the top 100.

River Plate are interested in signing Radamel Falcao, who played for them from 2001 to 2009. Falcao has struggled at Manchester United on loan this season, scoring only four goals. River Plate's vice president Matias Patanian expressed interest in Falcao returning, stating 'the doors are open.' Falcao has been in good form for Colombia recently, scoring three goals in two games to equal the country's all-time goalscoring record. He scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for River Plate during his first stint with the club.

Ella Henderson, the 19-year-old X Factor finalist, has been announced as the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and marks Henderson's first brand collaboration. The campaign features the singer with her hair styled in various ways, showcasing her versatility. The campaign launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single, "Mirror Man." Henderson herself uses the product regularly and is excited about the collaboration.

A billboard featuring the photo of officer Pablo Torres and his dog has been erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin, thanking the community for their support. The billboard is controversial as it features the officer who fatally shot Aaron Siler, 26, on March 14. Siler was armed and had an active felony warrant when he was shot after a vehicle and foot pursuit. The Kenosha Professional Police Association claims the billboard is not meant to offend and is simply a gesture of gratitude for community support during difficult times, including the recent shootings involving Torres. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border. Three militants were also killed. The militant group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack. Iran has criticized Pakistan for failing to control terrorists. Pakistan condemned the attack and promised to apprehend any militants who entered their territory after the incident.

The Japanese Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirmed that the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object. Despite Antonio Inoki's query about the possibility of alien threats, Nakatani stated that the ASDF has only encountered birds and other non-threatening objects. Inoki, a former wrestler and politician, is known for his colorful personality and advocacy for peace through sports, having engaged in high-profile matches and diplomatic efforts, including a wrestling tournament in North Korea. The discussion about UFOs and extraterrestrial threats is not new in Japanese politics, with previous officials also considering the implications of such encounters within the context of Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old man named Jin Pai was hospitalized after breaking a toilet in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport while squatting on it due to cleanliness concerns. The porcelain toilet collapsed, causing deep cuts on his leg and buttocks. He initially called for help from friends but was too embarrassed to shout for assistance. After being found and taken to the hospital for several dozen stitches, he reportedly changed his story from squatting to sitting when questioned by police, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities believe the incident was an accident and remind people that toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a girl in her home over a four-year period and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began when the 15-year-old girl found the camera in March. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including juveniles, and stated he purchased the camera specifically to record the girl while undressing and showering. He uploaded the videos to his computer. The abuse reportedly began when the girl was nine years old, and Rebbie would enter her bedroom while she was sleeping to molest her. Rebbie's relationship with the girl's family is unknown, and his preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1 with bail set at $500,000.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series captures po-faced teenagers next to their fathers leaping into the air. The daughters smile directly at the camera, while the fathers, dressed in suits, pull dramatic and energetic poses. The images are part of a book titled "Daughter and Salaryman," and they aim to show the fun side of fathers who are often serious, expressing excitement and hope through their jumps. The curious nature of the photos has generated interest online.

Kevin Pietersen looked deep in thought at a Surrey team photo shoot ahead of the start of the County Championship season. The batsman, who was controversially axed from the England team in 2014, was otherwise in a jovial mood. The event at the KIA Oval comes before Surrey begin their campaign against Glamorgan on April 19. Pietersen's return to Surrey is seen as a step towards forcing his way back into the Test set-up, with England aiming to regain the Ashes this summer.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt has fired Brazilian coach Ze Maria for a second time after a poor run of results, despite previously reinstating him. Ze Maria, a former Brazil international with 25 caps, was sacked after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani left the team 16th in the standings, six points from safety. He was the third coach of the season for Ceahlaul and will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao, a former Monaco teammate of Nabil Dirar, moved to Manchester United on loan last summer but has struggled to perform as he did before a serious knee injury. Despite not being happy in France, Dirar believes Falcao may regret leaving Monaco, as he would have played in the Champions League and possibly found more atmosphere. United are unlikely to make the transfer permanent due to Falcao's poor goal record and the high transfer fee of £46million.

On Saturday, a very tall man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy in New Zealand. He demanded cash from the owner's daughter, causing her to flee the shop screaming 'robber!' The man threw the cash register to the ground and took off with the till drawer containing up to $1500. The police were called but found no signs of a weapon. They are now appealing to the public for help in identifying the man, emphasizing that he remains at large.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice. She was first arrested on March 19 for having an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, admitting to kissing him and allowing him to touch her breasts. She was released on bail. Days later, on March 24, another 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January. Granado was arrested again on Monday and released after posting $50,000 bail. She is accused of having sex with the second student near another school in Dallas. The school district has placed her on administrative leave, preventing her from working with students or being present on school property.

A video of a crocodile with a dead dog in its jaws has been viewed over half a million times online. The incident occurred in the marina of Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, where crocodiles are a common sight due to the nearby sanctuary and their natural habitat in the mangroves. The dog belonged to the local bike shop owner and was attacked when it approached the water's edge to see the crocodile. The crocodile held the dog for hours without moving, and the video of the event has sparked reactions of horror and disgust on social media.

Hull City manager Steve Bruce is confident his team can avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton. Hull are currently two points clear of the relegation zone with six games left, including tough fixtures against top teams. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players. Southampton moved up to fifth place in the table after the win, but manager Ronald Koeman had to remind Sadio Mane about team rules after the player tried to take a penalty when James Ward-Prowse was the designated taker.

A primary school teacher named Ian Guffick has been banned from teaching for at least two years after he allowed pupils to alter their SATs exam answers, invalidating the entire school's results. The incident occurred at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire. Guffick admitted to the misconduct, which involved changing answers himself and asking pupils to make their answers more legible, but the conduct panel found his actions amounted to unacceptable professional conduct. The Department for Education annulled the school's SATs results following an investigation. The panel, chaired by Martin Pilkington, acknowledged Guffick's remorse but emphasized that his actions were dishonest and could not be excused by pressure to achieve good results. Paul Heathcote, acting on behalf of Education Secretary Nicky Morgan, imposed the ban, noting the serious impact on the school and the deliberate nature of Guffick's actions. Guffick has 28 days to appeal the decision to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, the Manchester United goalkeeper, married Swedish model Misse Beqiri last year. They have a son together and have been dating since 2012. Lindegaard has struggled for playing time at United, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons. Despite his limited game time, he is happy with his personal life, as evidenced by his Instagram post about spending time with his 'sunshine' Misse.

The 13 glowing blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium failed to find a buyer at a Sotheby's auction on Wednesday. The letters, which were installed in 1976 and removed in 2008, were expected to fetch between $300,000 and $600,000 but received no bids. The current owner, Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, bought them after the stadium's closure and tried to auction them off to allow a new generation to enjoy them. Despite his efforts, the letters did not attract any genuine bidders, and the only bid came from a Sotheby's employee attempting to start the auction. Meanwhile, a Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, surprisingly sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities following their involvement in incidents involving nitrous oxide and shisha pipes. Rodgers has not disciplined the players but wants to move past the incident. He has also emphasized the importance of professionalism and the responsibilities that come with being elite sportsmen. The manager has not revealed whether he will recall Steven Gerrard for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, stating that his main focus is on guiding Liverpool into their first FA Cup final under his management.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil posted a picture on Twitter of himself relaxing with his dog after returning to London following Germany's 2-0 win over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. Ozil, who was signed from Real Madrid for £42.5million in 2013, missed Arsenal's match against Newcastle due to illness but has been in good form since returning from injury, scoring three goals and providing four assists since January. He has also claimed that he fits perfectly into English football due to its demanding schedule.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the club is very happy with manager Luis Enrique, who took charge last summer. Enrique is currently six games away from winning the La Liga title and has impressed Bartomeu with his performance. The president refuted rumors of Enrique's potential replacement in the summer, noting that Enrique is focused on the current season and has a contract until 2016. Enrique's side recently defeated Valencia 2-0, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, as they continue their pursuit of three trophies.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed to a new long-term contract that will keep him at the club until 2020. The deal is reportedly worth around £100,000 per week. Henderson is the third key player to extend his contract under manager Brendan Rodgers, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. He is expected to be considered for the role of club captain when Steven Gerrard leaves this summer. Talks with Raheem Sterling are on hold until the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, a Chelsea full-back, has stated his desire to remain at the club until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. He has struggled to establish himself at Chelsea but is committed to the club. Meanwhile, Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is emphasizing the importance of maintaining focus and winning every game in the Premier League title run-in. The team is preparing for nine challenging matches ahead.

Nathan Hughes, the Wasps No 8, had his three-match ban for accidentally injuring George North overturned on appeal. The incident occurred on March 27 when Hughes' knee collided with North's head as Hughes scored a try for Northampton. North was left unconscious and has been advised to take at least a month off due to concussion symptoms. The original disciplinary panel found Hughes' actions to be reckless, leading to a red card and a three-match ban. However, the appeal panel, after reviewing new evidence and hearing the case afresh, concluded that the incident was accidental and not an act of foul play. As a result, Hughes' ban was rescinded, allowing him to return to action immediately. Despite this, Hughes is not expected to play for Wasps until their match against Exeter on April 26.

The fiery sunsets seen in Washington on Sunday were caused by smoke from wildfires in Siberia. The smoke was carried across the Pacific Ocean by winds and combined with solar light to create the intense red hues. The smoke originated from farmers burning grass in their fields, which quickly spread due to strong winds, destroying dozens of villages. Rescue crews managed to put out the fires, but the lingering smoke affected air quality in parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The red and orange colors are more visible during sunrises and sunsets because the light travels through more atmosphere, allowing these colors to penetrate unfiltered. As the smoke dissipates, the sunsets will lose their reddish hue and air quality will improve.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis, Missouri had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. The car was found with red rims, red detailing, and an orange steering wheel. Schoenig was surprisingly positive about the changes and thanked the thieves for "pimping out" her car. She plans to have the car professionally cleaned due to the strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana. Schoenig is creating a smoothie named "Sexton on Wheels" to honor Mick Sexton, who located her car and notified police.

Manchester City players face losing £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The Premier League title holders have incentivised contracts for star players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure to stay within financial fairplay rules. The team is currently in fourth place, but their European hopes are in jeopardy after a defeat to Manchester United and a challenging fixture list ahead. The club's manager, Manuel Pellegrini, has acknowledged that their season has disintegrated after starting strongly. The team will play West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham Hotspur, Queens Park Rangers, and Swansea City in their remaining fixtures.

Manchester United's Under 18 team won 1-0 against Manchester City's Under 18s in a friendly match at Altrincham's Moss Lane. The match featured mostly English players, with 10 from Manchester. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free-kick. The game was praised for its skill and commitment, showcasing young talents who may deserve first-team opportunities in the future.

Joe Hart has praised Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a 'legend of the game' after Buffon's 147th cap against England. Hart, who earned his 50th cap in the same match, looks up to Buffon and is inspired by the Italian goalkeeper's longevity and skill at 37 years old. Hart aims to continue his international career and add to his 50 caps, hoping to learn from the likes of Buffon.

Chipotle, a popular Mexican restaurant, has decided to enter the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app. This collaboration will allow Chipotle to deliver burritos and other menu items to customers in 67 cities across the U.S. Customers should expect a 9% service charge and additional delivery fees starting at $5, depending on distance and demand. Chipotle has reportedly turned down previous delivery service offers but has now agreed to work with Postmates, which uses independent contractors similar to Uber drivers for delivery. The move comes as Chipotle has seen increased popularity among high-profile customers such as presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton. Other fast-food chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or have already implemented delivery services to tap into this growing market.

Bill and Denise Richard, the parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have called for the death penalty against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev to be dropped. They argue that pursuing the death penalty could lead to years of appeals and prolong their family's suffering. Instead, they advocate for Tsarnaev to spend the rest of his life in prison without the possibility of release and waive all rights to appeal. The Richards believe it is time to turn the page and look toward a better future for their family and for Boston.

A billionaire has converted a Boeing 747-8 into a luxury home, spending £400 million on customization over three years. The plane features a large dining room with an adjoining kitchen, multiple lounges, a 'state room', and an 'aeroloft' with eight beds. It also includes a master bedroom, office/guest bedroom, and a conference room. The interior is designed to resemble a luxury hotel, with plush furnishings and no traditional airline seating. The plane can accommodate the owner and dozens of guests.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying a Dragon spacecraft from Cape Canaveral, Florida, to the International Space Station. The rocket's first stage attempted to land on a drone ship but tipped over. The Dragon spacecraft will deliver supplies to the ISS and return with experiments and waste. SpaceX aims to reduce space travel costs by reusing rockets.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas on April 23. The winning couple, announced next Monday, will receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite for two nights, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience. The chapel, part of a permanent Graceland exhibit, is not associated with impersonators and is described as 'first-class' by Priscilla Presley.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League title race, despite being four points behind. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season, equalling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues this campaign. Liverpool won 2-0 against Newcastle United on Monday, with Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scoring the goals. Allen scored his first Anfield goal, and although he felt Newcastle had a strong penalty claim, he was pleased with the win following recent defeats.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home with a victory over Napoli in Serie A. Miralem Pjanic scored the only goal in the 25th minute after a swift counter-attack. Roma's goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made crucial saves in the second half to deny Napoli an equalizer. Roma moved four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, who play later on Saturday. Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches. The match was played under tight security due to past incidents between the two clubs' supporters.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played a goalless draw at the Keepmoat Stadium, resulting in a 0-0 match. The match highlights video on Doncaster's YouTube channel is just 27 seconds long, featuring only the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle, reflecting the lack of action during the game.

The passage describes Roland Giroux's unique interaction with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish. Despite the common belief that marine pets cannot interact with humans through touch like cats and dogs, Giroux has established a tactile bond with his fish. He gently strokes and massages the fish, which initially swims away but returns for more interaction. The fish, which used to share its tank with two other fish that bullied it, has become sociable and even swims up Giroux's arm. The daily 15-minute sessions of massage and play have become essential for the fish's happiness, indicating a deep bond between owner and pet. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and the redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes, an England cricketer known for his fiery character and occasional aggressive behavior. It mentions an incident where he broke his wrist by punching a locker after being dismissed. The passage highlights the importance of channeling his aggression positively and mentions a conversation with coach Peter Moores following a clash with Marlon Samuels. Stokes is praised for his ability to capture the imagination and his willingness to stand up to opponents like Mitchell Johnson. The passage also discusses the balance needed between allowing Stokes to express his natural exuberance and controlling his aggression to ensure he contributes runs and wickets. The article suggests that while there might be a case for playing a second spinner like Adil Rashid, England prefers to have Stokes and Chris Jordan in the team for their potential to grow and add excitement to the game.

The Wales vs Belgium Euro 2016 qualifier at the Cardiff City Stadium on June 12 is a sell-out with 33,000 tickets sold. Wales and Belgium are both on 11 points in Group B, but Belgium leads due to a better goal difference. The victory over Israel has raised expectations for Wales to qualify for the tournament in France. The match is preferred to be played at the Cardiff City Stadium by the players and the venue cannot be changed due to UEFA rules within 120 days of the match.

John Peacock has named his England U17 squad for the UEFA European Championship in Bulgaria. The team, defending champions, includes players from various Premier League clubs like Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold. They will face Italy, Holland, and the Republic of Ireland in Group D and start their campaign against Italy on May 7.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht midfielder Evangelos Patoulidis. He is considered one of the top talents from Anderlecht's youth academy and has also caught the eye of Arsenal and Barcelona. Despite interest from Barcelona's La Masia, Patoulidis chose to stay in Belgium due to his family's wishes for him to continue his education. He has continued to perform well, and Manchester City have been in talks with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to negotiate a transfer and compensation package. The club aims to build for the future by acquiring promising young players like Patoulidis.

A 33-year-old transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found strangled and beaten to death in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death and has been bailed pending further questioning. Police are appealing for information from anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death.

Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, accused her friend Jamie, a convicted burglar, of stealing money set aside for a gravestone for her baby Daniel James. On The Jeremy Kyle Show, a lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt. He confessed via a Facebook message during the journey to the show, blaming his girlfriend Carol. Dawn was devastated, saying the money was for a gravestone to show her love for her son.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women and children, as well as the ill and elderly. The release was facilitated by Arab tribal leaders and the freed Yazidis were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil. The motivation for the release is unclear, but it follows previous releases of Yazidis, particularly children and the elderly. Yazidis are a minority group of Kurdish descent, whose religion is a blend of various ancient faiths, and they have historically faced persecution. The attack by ISIS last summer led to a humanitarian crisis, including mass displacement and reports of atrocities against Yazidis, including killings and enslavement of women. The international community responded with aid drops, rescues, and airstrikes against ISIS in Iraq and Syria.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham striker, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. He has had an incredible season, scoring 20 Premier League goals and breaking into Roy Hodgson's England side. A new animation celebrating his best goals and celebrations this season has been released by Copa90 ahead of the awards ceremony on Sunday, where he competes against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Former Liverpool defender Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers should remain as manager despite Liverpool's trophyless season and likely failure to qualify for the Champions League. Carragher, who won numerous honours during his playing days at Liverpool, stated that Rodgers needs to identify areas for improvement and make the right signings to propel the team forward. He also praised Rodgers for his work with the current squad and the staff's commitment to improving for next season. Carragher was honored with a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, reflecting his dedication to giving back to the community from which he came.

A four-year-old boy named James Hayward had his toy Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after security deemed it a security risk. The toy, which fires sponge darts, was in his hand luggage for a flight to Lanzarote. Security officers frisked James and performed a pat-down inspection on him. His father, Phil, a software engineer, criticized the security checks as 'ludicrous' and said they missed their flight due to the delay. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience but defended their actions by stating that no items resembling prohibited items are allowed through security, as per government regulations. The airport offered to post the toy back to the family's home but they declined.

The passage describes a man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, who posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. The man, who identifies himself as "Rich," is 31 years old, athletic, heavily tattooed, and owns his own properties. He is looking for a non-drinking, non-smoking woman who is fit, attractive, reliable, and good with domestic tasks. Rich offers benefits such as a free gym membership, a phone of her choice, and potentially a company car and accommodation. He emphasizes enjoying the outdoors and being good in bed as important qualities. He is also not shy about spending money on his partner and promises to consider all reasonable offers. Former partners are not welcome to apply.

The passage discusses the efforts of FA chairman Greg Dyke to increase the number of home-grown players in Premier League squads from eight to twelve. It mentions that Dyke wants to redefine "home-grown" to mean players trained in England for three years before the age of 18, rather than before 21. The proposal is supported by five former England managers: Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren. They warn that blocking these proposals could harm the English game and further diminish England's chances of winning the World Cup. The current situation is highlighted by the fact that only 36.8% of Premier League starters in the last round of matches were eligible for England selection. The letter from the former managers emphasizes that while England has produced talented young players like Barkley, Sterling, and Kane, they lack the opportunity to play at the top level. They argue that increasing the number of home-grown players will provide these young talents with the necessary opportunities to develop and compete on the world stage.

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, is now the mother of a new baby daughter in the show. The timeline of the pregnancy is fast-forwarded, with Demelza going from barely showing to being eight months pregnant in a very short span of time, and giving birth shortly after. The show's previous pregnancy storyline involving Elizabeth also featured a rapid progression. Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, is a character who many fans are drawn to, but his heart is portrayed as being committed to Demelza.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to focus on their own performances and not get distracted by the results of their relegation rivals in the Premier League. Leicester are currently three points above the relegation zone after two consecutive wins, including a last-minute victory against West Bromwich Albion. Pearson is cautious about becoming overly optimistic and wants his team to concentrate on their remaining fixtures to secure their Premier League status.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This surpasses the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's journey included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she might be an eastern gray whale rather than a western gray whale, which could have implications for the conservation status of the western gray whale population.

A landslide on Hokkaido Island's Shiretoko Peninsula caused a 1,000ft stretch of seabed to rise above the water overnight, creating a new coastline. The land rose 30 to 50 feet above sea level and measures 1,000 to 1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide. Local residents reported no tremors or sounds before the land appeared. Geologists believe the emergence is a result of the landslide, which was likely caused by melting ice and snow. The new land is not expected to expand further.

Gregory van der Wiel, a Dutch footballer playing for Paris Saint-Germain, has denied plans to leave the club in the summer despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc over his playing time. He expressed his love for the club, the city, and his teammates, stating his desire to sign a new contract and stay at PSG. Despite his intentions, the club is reportedly interested in signing Dani Alves from Barcelona, which could impact Van der Wiel's future at the club.

Carlos Tevez wants to leave Juventus to return to Boca Juniors. The Serie A club's president Daniel Angelici has said Tevez must terminate his contract first. The 31-year-old Argentine international joined Boca's youth academy in 1996 and has scored 26 league goals in 76 appearances for the club. He has reportedly told Juventus he wants to leave this summer. Tevez is the Serie A's top scorer with 17 goals this season.

Pep Guardiola, the Bayern Munich manager, accidentally tore a hole in his trousers during the Champions League match against Porto at the Allianz Arena. The incident occurred as Bayern led 5-0 at halftime, and the excitement of the match caused the rip. Despite the wardrobe malfunction, Bayern went on to win 6-1, securing their place in the Champions League semi-finals. Guardiola joked about needing to buy new underwear for the next match due to the exposure.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale, involving ten people, including four children. Three vehicles collided, resulting in injuries to several individuals. Two adults and two children were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital with more severe injuries, while six others, including an infant, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. The highway was closed for several hours, with diversions in place.

Arsenal's Mesut Ozil has a new Apple Watch and is excited for the match against Chelsea on Sunday. Arsenal are second in the Premier League, 10 points behind Chelsea. Jack Wilshere has returned from injury and is expected to play a big role in Arsenal's midfield. Ray Parlour, a former Arsenal legend, believes Wilshere is the future of the club if he can stay fit. Parlour compared Wilshere's injury history to that of Abou Diaby.

Referee Mark Clattenburg, known for sending off three players from both Manchester United and Manchester City this season, will officiate the Manchester derby at Old Trafford on Sunday. Despite past accusations of favoring United, Clattenburg has sent off only two Premier League players this season, both from United - Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw. The match is significant as it could determine the second-place finisher behind expected champions Chelsea, with United currently leading City by a point. City captain Vincent Kompany is suspended for the derby due to a red card received during Belgium's Euro 2016 qualifier against Israel.

Federal MP Bob Katter has accused the Queensland Government of assuming that embattled MP Billy Gordon would resign after being accused of domestic violence and concealing his criminal past. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, claims he has experienced racism from both major parties and sympathizes with Gordon's position. He questions why Gordon's resignation was assumed when similar cases in the federal parliament did not lead to such expectations. Katter's statement has sparked criticism for his use of the term "black puppet on a string," which he defends as a reflection of his personal experiences and a callout of perceived racial attitudes. He emphasizes that he believes Gordon will not become a puppet for the government, unlike some independent MPs in the past.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, has cerebral palsy but is using her dancing videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. She hopes to change the way people with disabilities are represented in television, film, and fashion. Despite facing bullying and judgment, Dayna aims to show that people with disabilities are not so different and can achieve many of the same things as anyone else. She has created several dancing videos and has started motivational speaking engagements at local schools.

Orlando City, coached by Adrian Heath, have shown interest in signing Javier Hernandez from Manchester United. Hernandez has struggled during his loan spell at Real Madrid but remains a target for several European clubs including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Manchester United have also made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from Paris Saint-Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

A gang attempted to carjack a man at a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday morning. When the driver refused and fled, the suspects poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger and set it on fire while two passengers were inside. No one was injured, but the car was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, has surrendered his license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. Despite these actions, he has received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com, with three patients giving him a perfect five out of five stars. Manuel has agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove that the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist before he can practice again.

A U.S. reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian fighter jet over the Baltic Sea in international airspace. The Pentagon criticized the Russian pilot's actions as unsafe and unprofessional due to aggressive maneuvers at high speed. The Russian Defense Ministry claimed the U.S. plane had its transponder off, but the U.S. European Command denied this. The U.S. plans to complain to Russia through diplomatic channels about the incident. This is not the first time the U.S. has complained about a close encounter between a RC-135U and a SU-27, with a similar incident occurring over the Sea of Okhotsk last year.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot. The theft occurred just days before President Obama visited Utah. The rifle was secured in a hard case inside the agent's car, which was broken into. The thief used a rope or cable lock and another vehicle's momentum to break the case free. The rifle, along with the agent's gear bag, backpack, and some clothing and tools, were stolen. The rifle case's handle was found broken off, and the stolen items were later found at a nearby hotel. The Secret Service was notified about the theft before Obama's visit, but it's unclear if security measures were increased. The stolen rifle has not been recovered.

In 2012, Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor Terrence Freebody in Canberra, Australia. A forensic psychiatrist, Professor Paul Mullen, testified that Costa was suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the murder, which affected his mental state and understanding of his actions. The evidence includes Costa's fluctuating mood during the incident, as indicated by his 000 calls, and a trail of faeces from the crime scene to the toilet, suggesting confusion. The prosecution claims Costa may have feigned memory loss during his interview with Professor Mullen, but the psychiatrist believes Costa's mental state was compromised by dementia and alcohol, leading to a confused state where he did not understand his actions or their consequences. The jury's decision hinges on proving Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack, which could result in a not guilty verdict.

Everton won 1-0 against Burnley at Goodison Park with a goal from Kevin Mirallas. Ross Barkley took a penalty in the 10th minute which was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton. Leighton Baines, Everton's regular penalty taker, was on the pitch but did not take the penalty. Roberto Martinez, the Everton manager, defended Barkley's decision to take the penalty, stating that several players are capable and it depends on how they feel at the moment. Baines was reportedly happy to let Barkley take the responsibility.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico. The incident occurred at 11:30 a.m. Thursday. The FBI is investigating the deaths, which are suspected to be a murder-suicide. The ship had departed from Tampa, Florida, on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and was in San Juan, Puerto Rico, at the time of the incident. The cleaning staff discovered the bodies after knocking on the cabin door.

Patrick Kluivert, a former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully guided Curacao into the second qualifying round of the 2018 World Cup in CONCACAF. Curacao achieved this by drawing 2-2 against Montserrat in the second leg, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team initially won the first leg 2-1 in Willemstad. In the decisive match, Charlton Vicento, a former Holland Under 21 international, scored the winning goal in the 87th minute. Curacao will now face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, has experience of World Cup semi-finals as a player in 1998 and as an assistant coach under Louis van Gaal in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, a former Inter Milan midfielder, believes that helping Leicester City stay in the Premier League would feel like winning a trophy. He views this challenge as equivalent to achieving a major success in his career, despite the team's current seven-point deficit with only eight games left in the season. Cambiasso, who has won numerous trophies including the Champions League, sees the effort to keep Leicester in the top flight as a significant goal. He remains optimistic about the team's chances despite their recent struggles and emphasizes that there is still a quarter of the Premier League season left to play.

A 23-year-old mother of two, named Gemma, is at risk of being banned from seeing her children due to her excessive drinking, partying, and suspected theft. Her mother, Debbie, who has been raising the children since they were four months old, is considering the ban because Gemma has not shown responsibility or care for her children. Debbie claims Gemma has a history of stealing and irresponsible behavior, including underage drinking and sex. The children call Debbie 'mum' instead of 'grandma', indicating Debbie's primary role in their upbringing.

Chelsea's John Terry was involved in a controversial challenge against Manchester United's Radamel Falcao during the build-up to Chelsea's opening goal. Terry's strong challenge from behind on Falcao was considered a foul by Sky Sports pundits Graeme Souness, Thierry Henry, and Jamie Redknapp. Souness described it as a "decent forearm smash" and Henry sympathized with Falcao as a striker. Redknapp acknowledged that while Falcao could have been stronger, the challenge was still a foul.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway Thursday morning, but everyone on board was safely evacuated. The fire started after a rear tire blew out and the bus burst into flames after everyone had gotten off. Scott and her husband, the tour manager, and the driver were all evacuated safely. The band is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday in Arlington, Texas, and the other two members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not traveling on the bus. Scott posted on Instagram that everything in the back lounge was destroyed except her Bible.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is researching space lasers that convert sunlight into energy. These lasers would not be powerful enough to harm people or planets, unlike their fictional counterparts. Instead, they would be used to generate and transmit solar power to Earth, potentially benefiting areas with limited sunlight or those affected by disasters. The technology is currently being tested in Scotland and may move to Portugal for further trials. The concept is distinct from a proposed laser system on the International Space Station designed to clear space debris, which also lacks the power to be used as a weapon.

Stephen Munden, 54, vanished from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, on Tuesday. He was last seen leaving the hospital at 6.15pm and officers believe he may have shaved off his beard. Munden, who suffers from learning difficulties, was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl. He was convicted of sexual offences last August and had admitted possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children. Police are appealing for information about his whereabouts.

V. Stiviano has been ordered to pay back more than $2.6 million in gifts by a Los Angeles judge after Donald Sterling's wife sued her. The gifts included luxury cars and a duplex. Sterling's downfall began when an audio recording surfaced of him making racist remarks to Stiviano, chastising her for posting pictures with African-Americans. The NBA banned Sterling, fined him $2.5 million, and terminated his ownership rights in the Clippers.

Thierry Henry believes Arsenal need to sign a goalkeeper, a center back, a defensive midfielder, and a top striker to compete for the Premier League title. He criticized Olivier Giroud as not being capable of leading Arsenal to the title and cited Chelsea's acquisitions of Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa as an example of what it takes to win the league. Henry also mentioned Arsenal's current third place in the league table, with a game in hand over Manchester City.

A young woman has spoken in court about the lasting impact of being sexually abused by Maurice Van Ryn, the former boss of Bega Cheese, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offenses, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who was abused as a child and didn't understand the abuse was wrong, kept silent until Van Ryn's arrest. She now suffers from depression, self-harm, and has attempted suicide, fearing the impact of the abuse on her future relationships and concerned about Van Ryn's eventual release.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old midfielder for Arsenal, has been out for over a year due to a serious knee injury. He last played for the first team in March 2014 against Bayern Munich in the Champions League. Gnabry has recently returned to action, playing 90 minutes for the Arsenal Under 21s against Reading on Monday. He expressed that he is feeling better and better as he recovers from his injury and is looking forward to his next game.

A 23-year-old accountant named Jacob Phillips died after falling 70 feet down a cliff while trying to avoid paying a taxi fare. He had been out drinking with friends in Cardiff and caught a taxi to Penarth, South Wales. Upon realizing they didn't have enough money for the fare, he and his friends decided to run away, with Jacob running in a different direction. He fell down a cliff at the end of the disused Northern Promenade, a rocky area, and was found dead the next day by a dog walker. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, noting that Jacob likely became disorientated and was unaware of the danger posed by the cliff.

The passage discusses a situation where thousands of holidaymakers experienced delays in receiving their passports last summer due to a fiasco at the HM Passport Office. Despite the chaos and the fact that the agency made a £42 million profit during this period, very few holidaymakers received compensation. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, with a total payout of £203,066, averaging just £92.68 per person. The highest single payout was £5,463, while the lowest was £1. The Home Affairs Committee chairman, Keith Vaz, expressed astonishment at the low number of compensations given, especially considering the agency's profit. Ministers rejected a blanket refund for those affected, stating it would set a precedent. The article also mentions that many holidaymakers contacted by the newspaper had either missed trips or paid extra for expedited passports but did not receive compensation. The HM Passport Office's bonus payouts to managers were also highlighted, with the average bonus being £499 and the highest being £3,500.

A 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, is up for sale with original features including stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro food tins. The semi-detached house has remained untouched for over 80 years and includes the original bathroom, kitchen, wood-panelled hallway, and vintage cupboards. The guide price is between £200,000 and £250,000. The house is a collector's paradise with features like mint and black bathroom tiles, stained-glass windows depicting ships and coats of arms, and original kitchen cupboards. Despite some modern upgrades like double glazing, potential renovation costs may deter developers. The property is set to be auctioned on April 30.

Colin Kaepernick started his NFL career as a backup to Alex Smith but took over as the starter in 2012 after Smith suffered a concussion. He led the San Francisco 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
"Soul Food" is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice, originally from New Orleans, moved to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 in New Jersey is a 3.45 mi freeway that connects the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast via NBCUniversal.

Damon Albarn, originally from Leytonstone, East London and Colchester, Essex, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon. Albarn is the frontman of the band Blur, which released its debut album "Leisure" in 1991. Blur's music is influenced by alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop. Albarn's solo debut, "Everyday Robots," co-produced by Richard Russell, was released in 2014 and features collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as samples from Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar locally, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It is home to many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by Nine Inch Nails from their EP Broken released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American BAFTA-nominated screenwriter born on August 14, 1964.

Both the 2007 film "Shooter" and the TV series "Shooter" feature a character named Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman. In the film, Swagger, played by Mark Wahlberg, is framed for murder by a secret military company. The TV series, starring Ryan Phillippe, follows Swagger as he returns from exile to thwart a plot to assassinate the president.
"House" is an American medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons from 2004 to 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder in 1971 for directing the killings of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate. He was also convicted for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. His followers carried out the killings. Manson's songs were released commercially after his arrest.

Sean Justin Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career with a small role in "Little House on the Prairie" in 1974, directed by his father Leo Penn. Penn gained recognition for his roles in films such as "At Close Range" (1986), "State of Grace" (1990), "Carlito's Way" (1993), and "Dead Man Walking" (1995), which earned him an Academy Award nomination and a Best Actor award at the Berlin Film Festival. He won his first Academy Award for Best Actor for "Mystic River" (2003) and his second for "Milk" (2008).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, often called "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman in the history of the sport. He was born on August 27, 1908, and passed away on February 25, 2001. Bradman's legacy in cricket extended beyond his playing career as he continued to influence the sport through administration, selection, and writing for over three decades after his retirement.
L.A. Reid has been the chairman and CEO of Epic Records, the president and CEO of Arista Records, and the chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer known for his work in the bands Rage Against the Machine, Audioslave, and Prophets of Rage. He started his career with the band Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991. Rage Against the Machine is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

The Millers is a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, for a total of 34 episodes across two seasons. CBS announced the cancellation of the show on November 14, 2014, during its second season.

Ann Richards (1935-1982) was an American jazz singer, and Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933-2006) was the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. She was the second female governor of Texas and delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention as state treasurer. Richards was defeated in her re-election bid in 1994 by George W. Bush.
Drake Bell released an EP titled "A Reminder" independently in 2011.

"Boardwalk" is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, wrote the film's screenplay and also wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios, also known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader born on July 24, 1783, and died on December 17, 1830. He was instrumental in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as independent sovereign states, freeing them from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is an area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships are reported to have mysteriously disappeared.

Colin Kaepernick began his NFL career as a backup but became the starter for the San Francisco 49ers in 2012 after Alex Smith suffered a concussion. He led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, which they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In his first full season as a starter in 2013, Kaepernick led the 49ers to the NFC Championship, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
"Marnie" is a 1964 American psychological thriller directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a form of marketing communication that uses nonpersonal messages to promote products, services, or ideas. It is conveyed through various media, including traditional platforms like newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, outdoor advertising, and direct mail, as well as newer channels such as search results, blogs, websites, and text messages. The key difference between advertising and personal selling is that advertising is not directed at a specific individual.

Private Lives is a 1930 comedy by Noël Coward, and a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin. Both are adaptations of the same source material, a comedy of manners in three acts.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician and Prime Minister from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice, in 384 BC. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at the age of seventeen or eighteen and stayed there until he was thirty-seven. After Plato's death, Aristotle left Athens and tutored Alexander the Great from 343 BC at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Mordechai Packouz is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine, and is the CEO of music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson, a point guard for the Lakers, won five NBA championships in 13 seasons with the team. He was the first overall pick in the 1979 NBA draft after excelling in high school and college. Johnson retired twice, first in 1991 and then again in 1996 after a brief return, and was a part owner of the Lakers. He is recognized for his significant influence in business and was named one of America's most influential black businessmen by Ebony magazine in 2009.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in 1994 in Los Angeles, California. The band consists of Jack Black on vocals and guitar, and Kyle Gass on guitar and vocals. They have released three albums: "Tenacious D" (2001), "The Pick of Destiny" (2006), and "Rize of the Fenix" (2012). They gained popularity in 1997 with their TV show and by touring with major rock acts.

James VI and I, also known as James Stuart, was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603. He sought a unified parliament for England and Scotland but encountered resistance, particularly in England, where he faced issues such as the Gunpowder Plot in 1605 and frequent conflicts with Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality TV show. It is hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley, a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist born on October 4, 1967. Bentley is best known for narrating the UK version of Big Brother since 2000 and has also done continuity announcements for Channel 4 until 2011. He is recognized for his distinctive Geordie accent and voice-over work.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state of Germany, bordered by several other German states and neighboring countries. It is the tenth largest state by area and the sixth most populous, with a population of 4 million. Historically, Saxony has a rich background spanning over a millennium. Today, it is known for being one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe, located in the eastern part of Germany.
East End Park was a former major league baseball park in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood. "In the End" is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown, also known as Scary Spice, began her solo career by releasing "I Want You Back" with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. It was released on July 1, 1994, and became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year. The film received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Initially, Divya Bharti was cast in the female lead but had to be replaced by Raveena Tandon after Bharti's death. The film is notable for its popular soundtrack.
"Hourglass" is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure, which is featured on James Taylor's fourteenth studio album, also titled "Hourglass."
Shane Black is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor. He is known for writing the 1987 action film Lethal Weapon and directing the film Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond film, featuring Roger Moore as James Bond for the seventh and final time.

Papua is the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, located on western New Guinea. It was previously known as Irian Jaya and before that as West Irian or Irian Barat, and it originally comprised all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus, the first Roman Emperor, likely died from natural causes, though there were unconfirmed rumors suggesting his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez is a singer and actress who debuted in the music industry in 1999 with her album "On the 6". She achieved a milestone by having a number one album and film simultaneously in 2001. Her relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her third album "This Is Me ... Then" and was released around the same time as the critically panned movie "Gigli". After her divorce from Marc Anthony, Lopez returned to prominence with her role on "American Idol" and the hit single "On the Floor".

A working animal is a domesticated animal trained by humans to perform tasks. These tasks can include guiding the visually impaired, providing tractive force for pulling loads, milking, herding, or entertainment. True working animals are typically characterized by trustworthiness and mild temper, distinguishing them from wild animals that may be trained for novelty or entertainment purposes.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. It was released directly to video. Top Latin Albums is a Billboard chart for Spanish language full-length albums, considered the most important chart for Latin music in the American market. The Regional Mexican Albums chart is another Billboard genre-specific chart for albums in the Regional Mexican music category.

"Vedam" is a 2010 Telugu drama film directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi. It stars Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham. The film explores various narratives that converge in the climax.
Men in Black II is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film featuring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a character in Don Quixote, written by Miguel de Cervantes in 1605. He is Don Quixote's squire and provides humorous, proverbial, and witty comments throughout the novel, known as "sanchismos."
"The Adventures of Pluto Nash" is a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role and directed by Ron Underwood.
The world premiere of Hedda Gabler took place on January 31, 1891, at the Residenztheater in Munich, with Henrik Ibsen in attendance.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth is an English actor and director, born on May 14, 1961.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A., commonly known as Juve, is an Italian professional football club founded in 1897 in Turin, Piedmont. It is the second oldest active football club in Italy, established by a group of students including Eugenio Canfari, who became its first president. The club is known for its black and white striped home kit since 1903 and has played at various stadiums, currently the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation, and the final decision rests with Welsh government ministers.

The passage discusses a meeting of Chechen Muslim clerics on April 3rd, two days after a newspaper report, where they condemned the report as an insult to their faith and the dignity of Chechen men. The clerics' resolution stated that "retribution will catch up with the true instigators," which Novaya Gazeta interpreted as a call for reprisals against journalists. The newspaper had previously reported on April 1st that over 100 people were detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report and described torture methods used against detainees. Ramzan Kadyrov, the authoritarian leader of Chechnya, denied the allegations, claiming there were no gay people in Chechnya. The mufti of Chechnya, Salah-haji Mezhiev, supported the resolution's call for retribution. Novaya Gazeta's editor Dmitry Muratov defended the report and called for dialogue, noting that the paper's journalists would continue investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya. The passage also mentions that Chechens have been linked to the murders of journalists investigating crimes in Chechnya, including Anna Politkovskaya and Natalia Estem

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, has been receiving significant housing benefit payments by placing multiple single homeless men in one property and charging for each, thereby increasing the benefit payout beyond the actual rent fee to landlords. The company, founded by Samir Patel in 2002, operates in close proximity to its associated charity, Fresh Start Housing, which Patel also established in 2010. Fresh Start Housing aims to help reduce poverty and distress among current and ex-offenders by providing housing. Despite neither organization acting illegally, their practices have been criticized as exploitative and prioritizing profit over the welfare of tenants. Fresh Start Housing has housed 788 homeless people since its inception and 222 in the last year. The relationship between the charity and the letting agency has been described as a "new low" by a homeless group. Wandsworth Council, a major payer of housing benefit to Investing Solutions, claims to ensure the safety, security, and affordability of private rented sector housing through dedicated teams. The Department for Communities and Local Government states that local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayers' money through rigorous inspections and investigations.

The Great Britain men's basketball team was led by Andrew Lawrence's 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon's 13 points in a game against the Netherlands. The home team led for most of the first three quarters but was overtaken in the last 10 minutes, losing the match. Coach Joe Prunty emphasized the importance of playing hard on both offense and defense for the upcoming Eurobasket qualifying campaign. He highlighted the need to maintain intensity throughout the games. Prunty was pleased with Ben Gordon's performance, noting that Gordon found his rhythm and contributed significantly during the third quarter. The team will now travel to Hungary for their next game in the qualifiers.

The passage discusses the waiver submitted by Conor McGregor to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use 8oz gloves in his boxing match against Floyd Mayweather. The NAC had a deadline for this waiver and McGregor submitted it just in time. The NAC rules state that fights at 154 lbs require 10oz gloves, but there is a provision to use lighter gloves if both fighters agree and the NAC finds it justified. Mayweather had previously expressed his intention to use 8oz gloves, but he had not submitted the necessary waiver document until McGregor did. The NAC will debate the use of 8oz gloves on August 16th. The passage also mentions criticism of the fight from boxing personalities, the role of Nate Diaz in shaping the NAC's opinion of McGregor's boxing skills, and the hiring of Joe Cortez as the referee for the fight.

Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism, is closing its last office as the Sunday Post shuts down its London operation. The street, synonymous with the nation's biggest newspapers, was home to iconic titles and the pinnacle of a journalist's career. The first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, was published there in 1702. At its peak, Fleet Street was bustling with journalists, bars, and the sound of typewriters. The closure marks the end of an era, with the last two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, reflecting on their experiences and the rich history of the place. The move away from Fleet Street began in the 1980s with the introduction of new technology and the relocation of major newspapers to other parts of London. The legacy of Fleet Street, however, remains an integral part of British journalistic history.

J.K. Rowling has faced criticism on Twitter for her political donations and views, particularly regarding the Scottish independence referendum. She has donated Â£1m to the No campaign and Â£1m to the Labour party. After being called a "traitor" and experiencing abusive comments, she blocked some users she believed were SNP supporters. Despite this, she engaged with other SNP supporters who were respectful and found common political ground. Rowling responded humorously to a suggestion that her books should be burned, saying she would bring marshmallows. The SNP's significant victory in the recent UK election is also mentioned.

The study by University of Edinburgh researchers found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action compared to their wealthier peers who commit the same crime. Living in poverty increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. The research highlights that poverty increases the risks of violence and contact with the juvenile justice system exacerbates the conditions for violence. The study also reveals that areas with the most chronic crime rates do not benefit from the overall fall in crime rates in Scotland. The Scottish government claims that Scotland is becoming a safer place, with crime at a 41-year low, and they are tackling poverty and inequality through various initiatives.

Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway in Kilkee, Marian estate, in the early hours of Sunday. Robbie Walsh, 25, from Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh. Two other men were arrested but released without charge. The incident involved a fight where weapons were used, and other individuals also became involved. Gardaí recovered a knife handle and a blade at the scene, with blood on the blade. Mr Haugh was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital. The accused, Robbie Walsh, was remanded in custody until 14 August.

The summary of the passage is as follows: In May 2014, Phil Flanagan, an MLA from Fermanagh, tweeted a comment about Tom Elliott, an MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, suggesting he harassed and shot people while serving in the Ulster Defence Regiment (UDR). The tweet was deleted within an hour and Flanagan later apologized, admitting the tweet was untrue and without foundation. Mr. Justice Stevens is to decide on the compensation amount. The insurance firm that covers MLAs at Stormont refused to cover Flanagan for this case, prompting Flanagan to take legal action against the insurance decision separately.
