This marks their return to the National League under manager John Still, who previously took the club from the Conference to League One. Dagenham have struggled this season, with the worst goal difference in League Two and conceding 20 more goals than they did at this point last term. Jamie Cureton, the club's leading scorer, has managed only nine goals this season compared to 20 in the 2014-15 campaign. Leyton Orient, now managed by Andy Hessenthaler following Kevin Nolan's removal, are two points behind the play-off spots. John Still, Dagenham's manager, acknowledged his team's lack of discipline and organization in the first half as key factors in their defeat.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard is returning to the club as a youth coach in February. This will be his first job since retiring as a player. Jurgen Klopp, Liverpool's manager, spoke positively about Gerrard's future aspirations in management, noting that Gerrard expressed a desire to become a manager and that he has a bright future in the field. Gerrard played for Liverpool from 1998 until 2015 and has since retired from playing. He is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching licence and had been linked with the manager's job at MK Dons, but felt the opportunity came "too soon" for him.

Summary: McManus scored twice, and Johnstone and Forbes also found the net as Morton defeated Alloa comfortably. McManus opened the scoring in the 15th minute, Forbes doubled the lead soon after, McAusland scored for Alloa before halftime, and McManus and Johnstone added late goals for Morton.

The summary of the passage is that Ofsted has discovered illegal schools operating in squalid conditions in Birmingham, which have since been closed. The operators of these schools could face up to 51 weeks in jail. The government is consulting on plans to increase regulation of places that teach for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, the Chief Inspector of Schools, expressed concern that these cases are likely just the "tip of the iceberg" and that children are at risk of abuse or radicalization. The investigation has uncovered 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands. Three Birmingham locations have been closed, and the owners are under investigation. The passage also mentions that places providing support for home-educated children can operate legally if they follow certain guidelines, but some are exploiting the system to run illegal schools. The government has funded a team of inspectors to investigate illegal schools, and the regulations will apply to any religious group operating such schools in unsafe conditions. The education secretary has announced plans to prepare cases for prosecution against identified unregistered schools and has called for further regulation through a consultation running until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is set to be the first whisky distillery in the Scottish Borders since 1837. The gin production is on a small scale, using local Teviot valley wild food to capture the local flavor palette and 'terroir'. The name Lilliard Gin is inspired by Lilliard, a legendary Borders figure from the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. The distillery aims to complement the ethos of local sourcing shared with the Scottish Borders Brewery on the site.

Harry Whitlam, 16, died in 2013 when Gary Green, who was over twice the legal driving limit, reversed a tractor into him at a farm. Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail for failing to ensure safety on private land. The tragedy has left Harry's family devastated, with his mother Pam Whitlam stating that their close-knit family has been changed forever. She emphasized the importance of not driving under the influence, whether on public roads or private land. The case was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law because it occurred on private property.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguayan striker, has been allowed to train and play in friendly matches by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), despite his appeal against a four-month ban for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini being rejected. He will join Barcelona's training on Friday and there will be a presentation on Monday, but his competitive debut with the club is likely to be against Real Madrid on October 26. Suarez will still serve the remaining eight games of his ban in competitive international matches. He can now play in friendlies for Uruguay in September and October. Cas ruled that preventing Suarez from all football-related activities was excessive, as it would affect his preparation after the ban ends. The decision was welcomed by Suarez's lawyers, who argued that Fifa's punishment was too harsh. Fifpro, the world players' union, expressed disappointment that Cas did not significantly reduce the sanctions. Suarez, who joined Barcelona for £75m, will also be allowed to attend matches and participate in promotional activities.

The passage describes a unique race where participants carry their partners over a challenging 380-meter course that includes hurdles, a steep slope, and water pistols. The event is open to all combinations of competitors, not just married couples. Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won the race, and they will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The UK government is replacing the paper car tax disc system with an electronic one in October. This change is expected to lead to a reduction in job roles at the DVLA, but the minister assures that any reduction in staff will be managed through redeployment to other areas of the business, rather than redundancies. The minister also noted that the switch to monthly direct debit payments for car tax may naturally reduce the need for processing refunds, contributing to the change in job roles. Swansea East AM Mike Hedges welcomed the minister's assurances and expressed support for the new system despite the anticipated job role changes.

The Hungarian government, led by Viktor Orban, is facing criticism from the EU over three controversial laws: tight controls on asylum seekers and NGOs, and a higher education law that could force the closure of the Central European University (CEU). Despite the EU's objections, Hungarian Minister Zsolt Szijjarto insists that these laws are a matter of national competence and that the EU should not interfere. He claims to have Poland's support in vetoing any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU requires unanimous approval for such decisions, and Hungary's right-wing Fidesz government is standing firm against pressure to withdraw the laws. The Higher Education Law could lead to the closure of the CEU, founded by philanthropist George Soros, and the draft legislation on NGOs is expected to further restrict their operations.

The live-action adaptation of Disney's Beauty and the Beast will star Emma Watson as Belle and Dan Stevens as the Beast. Angela Lansbury's iconic character Mrs. Potts will be portrayed by a new star, while Kevin Kline will play Belle's father Maurice. The film, directed by Bill Condon, will be released in the US on March 17, 2017, and will also feature Luke Evans as Gaston and Josh Gad as LeFou.

Adrian Gill, a columnist for the Sunday Times, has died suddenly after being diagnosed with multiple cancers. Known for his controversial and dazzling writing style, Gill was described by his editor as the "heart and soul" of the paper. He was a dyslexic writer who joined the Sunday Times in 1993 and wrote about his battle with cancer in a column last month. Despite his controversial views and articles, which included criticism of Wales, Rhyl, Norfolk, the Isle of Man, and TV presenter Clare Balding, Gill was remembered by colleagues and peers for his exceptional writing and compassion. He was married twice, had four children, and was engaged to his partner of 23 years at the time of his death.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa, was attacked in Ulan Bator after performing on stage wearing a traditional Mongolian robe with a swastika. The swastika is a pre-Nazi symbol in Mongolia representing eternity. The rapper was reportedly hit over the head with a bottle and kicked in the face by a Russian diplomat, who has not been arrested due to his diplomatic immunity. The rapper's father stated that his son spent 10 days in a coma after the attack. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident, calling local press reports "distorted." The swastika's origins are ancient, predating the Nazi use, and it is used in Mongolia to represent cultural identity. The musician's lawyer, father, and band member deny reports that he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the performance. The case is under investigation by Mongolian police, despite the suspect's diplomatic status.

A group called Plane Stupid staged a protest on the northern runway at Heathrow Airport at 03:30 BST on Monday. The protesters have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. They will appear in court on August 19th. The Metropolitan Police stated that airport security would be reviewed following the incident.

Glamorgan's Nick Selman scored a century, while Glamorgan's bowlers, including Matt Taylor and Craig Miles, kept Gloucestershire's batsmen under pressure. Gloucestershire struggled in response, with the match ending evenly balanced. Selman expressed satisfaction with his return to form after a tough patch, and Taylor highlighted the bowling conditions and his own performance.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old man from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after he communicated online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to planning to make a false report to the police, intending to lure officers to the Dee Estuary under the guise of a non-existent crime, with the aim of ambushing and shooting them. Hughes was under the influence of alcohol during these threats. He has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. He will be sentenced next week after being remanded in custody by Judge Niclas Parry. His legal team has stated that Hughes did not intend to kill himself and would not have carried out the threats against police officers.

The passage describes a cricket match where Yorkshire were chasing a target set by Surrey. Yorkshire were reduced to 8-2 but then scored 255-7, with Davies and Foakes contributing significantly with a partnership of 130 runs. Despite this, Yorkshire's run-chase was hindered by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker. Yorkshire's top order faltered, and although Tim Bresnan made 68, Yorkshire were all out for 236. Yorkshire were hoping to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002 but lost to Durham in the T20 Blast semi-finals last weekend. The passage also includes quotes from Surrey's Gareth Batty and Yorkshire's Alex Lees, reflecting on the match and their respective team performances.
A converted trawler 6 miles west of South Stack experienced engine trouble and was towed to Holyhead by the RNLI lifeboat after its pump failed to handle the incoming water. The trawler is 56ft long.

The core pieces of information from the passage are:

1. Laura Muir, a Scottish middle distance runner, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies.
2. Her exams are scheduled for May, and the Commonwealth Games take place in April, making it impossible for her to attend.
3. Muir expressed disappointment about missing the opportunity to run for Scotland at the Commonwealth Games.
4. She is focused on completing her final year of university studies.
5. Muir is considering competing in the World Indoor Championships in March.
6. She set a new outdoor personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in her race on Sunday.
7. Hellen Obiri won the women's 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, beating defending champion Almaz Ayana, with Sifan Hassan finishing third.
8. Muir is optimistic about her future in athletics and believes she has potential for multiple Olympic appearances.

Liverpool are a long way off repeating last season's title challenge and are struggling to match the intensity and pressing game that brought them success last year. The departure of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge have left a void up front, with Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini failing to fill the gap. The team's work-rate and effectiveness in the first half have significantly dropped, and they are currently struggling to score goals. The defense, despite significant investment, remains a concern, with Simon Mignolet's leadership and Kolo Toure's form being questioned. The midfield lacks runners beyond the striker, which was a key component of their play last season. Set-pieces, which were lethal last season, have also become a weakness.

Liverpool face Chelsea on Saturday, and the match is expected to be challenging due to Chelsea's current form and lack of weaknesses. The game will be emotionally charged for Steven Gerrard, who is facing questions about his future and recovery from the infamous slip against Chelsea last season. Despite these challenges, Gerrard is seen as a key player for Liverpool and is expected to continue his career at a top club, possibly even extending it beyond this season. His mental

A new educational campus costing £45 million is to be built in Kilmarnock, housing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. The facility will be named in honor of William McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock, who was passionate about education. McIlvanney, known for his contributions to literature as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," was an English teacher who later became a full-time writer. His works include the Laidlaw trilogy and other notable novels like "Docherty" and "The Big Man." The council leader expressed delight in preserving the McIlvanney name in Kilmarnock, highlighting his dedication to education. McIlvanney passed away in Glasgow on December 5, 2021.

The town near the swimming pool had to evacuate for several hours due to a sea mine discovered on Monday. The mine is believed to be British from the 1940s or 1950s. An exclusion zone remains in place on the river, and residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors. Ferry services from Gourock and Rothesay were disrupted. The mine's deterioration made it unsafe to determine its remaining explosive content, so it was decided to move it to a safer location before disposal. Inverclyde Council thanked residents for their cooperation during the evacuation and safety procedures.

The UK has announced funding cuts for several sports ahead of the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, including badminton, despite the sport achieving a medal at the Rio 2016 Games. Cycling, which won 12 medals in Rio, has seen its funding reduced by more than £4m to £25.98m. The total investment in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports is £345m, £2m less than the record £347m allocated for Rio. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. The decision to cut funding for sports like badminton and judo, despite their Rio performances, has been met with criticism from those sports' governing bodies.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff are to be demolished to make way for a new six-story, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The development, proposed by The East Cliff Project LLP, was approved by councillors despite objections from English Heritage and local residents due to concerns over the scale and impact on the conservation area. The approved plan includes a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments across two buildings. The decision was supported by the argument that the development would help tourism and provide improved living options for older people in the town. The buildings to be demolished are the Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels. The approval reflects a balance between preserving the town's tourism appeal and accommodating the needs of an aging population, with the understanding that the existing buildings had reached the end of their functional lifespan.

Private Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was fatally assaulted by Jake Vallely outside a Brecon bar named The Cellar on May 8, 2021. Vallely, who was 24 at the time, was found guilty of manslaughter and will be sentenced on December 8. Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was acquitted of the same charge as he was not present during the attack. The incident occurred after Vallely had been drinking heavily and boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon." The soldier's family described him as loving, caring, and loyal, and expressed their grief over the loss and the void left in their lives.

Andrew Travers, the former chief executive of Barnet Council, left the authority after an error led to voters being turned away from polling stations due to missing names on the electoral register. An independent investigation has been launched to examine the issue, which occurred during the EU Referendum. John Hooton will temporarily take over as chief executive, and the review is expected to conclude by the end of May.

Gateshead beat Wrexham 2-1 in a match where Josh Gillies scored the first goal with a free-kick. Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham with his own set-piece. Ryan Bowman then scored the winner for Gateshead with a header from a cross by Craig Baxter. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's performance, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills was disappointed with his team's second-half display and their inability to convert chances.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks countries based on the social and economic welfare of people over 60. Norway is ranked the best, while Afghanistan is the worst, followed by Mozambique.

The passage describes the launch of a new satellite network called OneWeb, which aims to provide global broadband internet coverage. The network will initially consist of 600 satellites but could expand to over 2,000. Airbus, a major space company, is involved in the project and has developed a new, more cost-effective manufacturing process to produce the satellites in high volume. This process involves automation and assembly line methods similar to those used in car and plane factories. The satellites are designed to be low-cost, with each unit costing less than a million dollars. The project is expected to revolutionize the satellite industry and is supported by significant investment and regulatory approval from the UK Space Agency. OneWeb plans to set new standards in debris mitigation by ensuring that old satellites are de-orbited within two years to prevent space junk accumulation. The article also mentions that while this high-volume approach is suitable for projects like OneWeb, other space missions requiring specialized satellites will still need traditional, more expensive manufacturing methods.

The Scottish government is facing spending cuts imposed by the UK government, with Finance Secretary Derek Mackay stating that the discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. Despite this, the UK government claims that Scotland will have £390m more in spending next year, rising to £750m when including its own underspend. The Scottish government is determined to protect key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police despite the cuts. The UK government's Scotland Office argues that the stability of the UK economy provides a better financial deal for Scotland, while Labour suggests that the Scottish government should focus on utilizing its new powers and making long-term budget decisions rather than focusing on grievances.

The passage discusses the critical need for Changing Places toilets, which are specially designed for individuals with severe disabilities who require more space and equipment for changing than standard accessible toilets provide. These toilets include features like a hoist and changing bench, and are advocated for by families and carers of disabled individuals. The current situation is that while recommendations exist for their installation in larger buildings, they are not compulsory. Campaigners are pushing for these guidelines to become mandatory in building regulations to ensure accessibility for a significant number of people who require these facilities. The passage highlights the emotional and practical challenges faced by families without access to Changing Places, including the stress of having to use unsuitable facilities and the psychological impact on the disabled individuals and their families. It also mentions positive examples of businesses and communities adapting to provide these facilities, such as Arsenal Football Club installing a Changing Places toilet and a friend creating a 'pop-up' Changing Place for a party. The overarching message is the importance of making these facilities mandatory in new constructions to ensure accessibility and inclusion for people with severe disabilities.

A group of Italian consumers' organizations has lodged a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, alleging that the fast-food giant forces its franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. The complaint is supported by the Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions, including the Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union in the UK. McDonald's, in response, states that it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees, a model that has been successful for many years. The European Commission will now study the submission and could launch an investigation if it finds the allegations credible. The consumer organizations claim that franchisees are locked into long contracts with McDonald's, lease premises at above-market rates, and are unable to switch to competitors, leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and McDonald's earned $9.27bn from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

The core pieces of information from the passage are:

1. A poster with the hashtag #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood, County Down, within the last week.
2. The poster is part of a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee.
3. Josh was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when he was supposed to have an operation for his appendix.
4. Doctors found and removed a large primary cancer and five smaller growths instead.
5. The hashtag originated from Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father works, and has gone viral.
6. The church's senior pastor, Gary Beattie, expressed surprise at the global support Josh has received.
7. A mystery donor paid for a large billboard with the hashtag to be erected at Holywood playing fields.
8. The hashtag has been widely used on social media, including by Josh's classmates at Bangor Grammar.
9. People all over the world are now supporting Josh, thanks to the viral campaign and the billboard.

The UK government has announced the closure of Brecon Barracks, a move that has been criticized by Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies. He argues that the barracks, established in 1805, has a rich history of service, including soldiers from there fighting in every conflict since the early 19th century. Davies condemns the decision as disrespectful to history and plans to fight it, citing the barracks' significance to the town's military tourism and the high unemployment levels in the area. The closure is part of a broader military estate reorganisation, which includes the creation of a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan and the previously announced closure of Cawdor Barracks in 2024. The decision has been met with concern over the impact on local livelihoods, with Labour's Nia Griffith emphasizing the need for support for those affected by the closures.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights the industry's historical discontent with the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and its hopes for regaining control over UK waters post-Brexit. However, it also warns that securing market access for UK fish exports to the EU might require concessions, such as allowing EU boats to fish in UK waters. The Lords EU Committee report emphasizes that while fishing is a small part of the UK economy, it should not be overlooked in the broader Brexit negotiations. The report suggests that some elements of the CFP should be retained and that the UK should continue to base quotas on scientific advice. It also raises concerns about the potential fragmentation of fisheries management regimes across the UK's constituent countries. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the opportunities Brexit may bring, citing recent quota increases as a positive sign. The government's response indicates its commitment to ensuring fair access to quotas and sustainable stocks while maximizing trade opportunities post-Brexit.

The former CIA worker Edward Snowden leaked documents revealing the extent of US surveillance. The National Security Agency (NSA) has access to chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, and more from major tech companies. The US government confirmed it requested millions of phone records from Verizon. The NSA's access to company servers is described as a "backdoor" but may be more limited than that. Different countries have different data protection laws, but these often do not cover government activity. The US Patriot Act allows American authorities to access data stored in other countries. The EU is seeking more details about Prism's impact on EU citizens. Privacy concerns have been raised about the internet and the extent of government surveillance.

OpenAI is a research company founded with $1 billion in funding from tech leaders like Elon Musk and Peter Thiel. The goal of OpenAI is to conduct AI research with a focus on positive human impact, free from financial pressures. The founders acknowledge the potential risks of AI, with Elon Musk calling it the biggest existential threat to humanity. Despite these concerns, they believe the benefits of AI can outweigh the risks if developed and used responsibly, aiming for an even distribution of AI technology to enhance individual human capabilities.

L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, a soldier seriously injured in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch in Doncaster. Despite being unable to speak due to his injuries, he is known for his personality and humor. He has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but the site limits personal pages to 5,000 friends. His mother, Diane, said the support has been phenomenal and that Ben is "buoyed up" by the messages of support and friendship. The family has received a lot of mail and email traffic, and Ben has been invited to many places to visit with the torch. Facebook suggests that Ben consider having a page instead of a profile or using the subscribe feature to manage his public updates due to his status as a public figure.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US was 15%, with 46.2 million Americans living in poverty. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6% in 2011, marking the first annual rise since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance dropped to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty in the US reached a record high in 2010 at 15.1%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013. He has scored England's three fastest One Day International (ODI) centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan. His new contract with Lancashire ties him to the club until 2019. Ashley Giles, the cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler for his talent and his contribution to the team, including helping Lancashire win the T20 Blast competition. Buttler has been playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians and will return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until January 23 to express interest in purchasing the ships. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. Bidders are finalizing their bids with viewings scheduled for late February and March. A decision is expected in the spring. The Disposal Services Authority wants at least one ship to go to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, supports UK recyclers but also favors saving at least one ship for a reef and diving attraction to generate tourism income. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to ensure the best financial return for taxpayers. The Type 22 frigates were designed as anti-submarine ships but evolved into multi-role combatants with significant weaponry and communication capabilities. HMS Ark Royal, an aircraft carrier, was sold as scrap for £3m last year.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced political and racial tensions leading to multiple coups, including in 1987, 2000, and 2006. These events have resulted in adverse effects on the economy, particularly the tourism industry, and have led to international isolation, such as suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with indigenous Fijians now forming a small majority due to emigration following political unrest. Despite relying on sugar and tourism, Fiji faces economic challenges including trade and budget deficits, and it is one of the world's largest per capita recipients of aid.

The passage discusses Syria's struggle to meet the deadline for the destruction of its chemical weapons amidst an ongoing civil war. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad claims that Syria is doing its best to comply but has faced challenges, including attacks on shipments of chemical weapons. He criticizes the US for not considering the war context and for supporting "terrorist elements" in Syria. The passage also mentions the use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, which has resulted in civilian casualties, and disputes between the Syrian government and opposition groups over the control of Aleppo's central prison. The country is behind schedule in the destruction of its chemical weapons, with only 4% of the stockpile removed so far. The OPCW acknowledges the delays due to security concerns, and Russia has urged Syria to complete the transfer of chemical weapons by March.

The Man Booker Prize for Fiction 2014 is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The front-runner is The Lives of Others by Neel Mukherjee, with bookmakers William Hill giving it odds of 5/2. The other shortlisted authors are Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan. The winner will be announced on Tuesday night at London's Guildhall.

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is appealing against a ruling that lifted a ban on naming him in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments about whether to grant his appeal and decide on its outcome. An interim injunction remains in place until the conclusion of the hearing. The man, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, is fighting against the publication of allegations about his alleged extra-marital activities by The Sun on Sunday. The Court of Appeal previously ruled in his favor, preventing his identification in publications in England and Wales. However, the judges lifted the ban due to the widespread nature of the story, which has been published internationally and spread across the internet and Twitter. The man's legal team has been trying to remove stories in breach of the injunction, but the judges deemed this effort "hopeless."

Fosse Park, a retail and leisure complex near the M1 junction 21, was purchased for £345.5m in August 2021. The new owners plan to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the units. They have met with Blaby District Council to address potential planning issues. The leaders of the council and the new owners agree that the park has become tired and they aim to enhance the common areas and facilities to improve the overall quality and experience for visitors.

The live-action remake of Disney's Beauty and the Beast has been approved for release in Malaysia after a "gay moment" sparked controversy. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit to the gay scene, despite homosexual activity being illegal in the Muslim-majority country. The film was initially held for a content review but has now been cleared for screening with a P13 parental guidance classification. The release date has not yet been announced.

Landlords in Southampton who rent to more than three unrelated people need a license for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO), which costs £1,000. Despite potential fines of up to £20,000 for not having a license, many landlords are deterred by the cost of the license. There are an estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Shelter, a helpline for housing advice, receives about five or six calls a day from tenants of HMOs who are concerned about living in poorly maintained properties and fear of eviction. The national requirement for HMO licensing applies to houses of three storeys or more with five or more unrelated occupants. In Southampton, the licensing applies in specific areas including Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (Designation 1), and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (Designation 2). The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for not complying with the HMO licensing regulations.

The leaders of Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil are trying to avoid a second election in Ireland. Fianna Fáil will allow Fine Gael to form a minority government but will not support a detailed policy plan. Water charges are a major issue preventing agreement. Fianna Fáil wants to abolish water charges immediately, while Fine Gael sees a need for them. The election resulted in no party gaining a majority, with Fine Gael having 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7.

The ferry The Sorrento caught fire while en route to Valencia. Passengers were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by another ship. Three people were injured, one seriously, and taken to hospital by helicopter. The fire started on one of the car decks around 17 miles from Mallorca. The cause of the fire is unclear, but several ships, including two passenger ferries, were dispatched to assist. The rescued passengers were transferred to another ferry, the Puglia, and were expected to return to Palma de Mallorca within a few hours. Psychologists were being prepared to offer counseling at the port. The Balearic Islands port authority tweeted that The Sorrento might sink in its current position. The Italian-owned ferry sent out distress signals at 11:50 GMT, and despite initial reluctance, a full evacuation was eventually ordered due to the intensity of the fire.

The Electoral Commission has highlighted concerns over duplicate voter registrations, particularly among students and those with second homes, following the general election. Despite a record number of people registering to vote, with 46.8 million registered, there were concerns about the number of duplicate applications, estimated to range between 30% and 70% in different areas. The Commission called for better integration between individual electoral registers and the online registration system to prevent duplicates and for a verification function similar to those in Australia, New Zealand, and the Republic of Ireland. It also stressed that voting twice in a general election is a criminal offense punishable by an unlimited fine. Labour warned against making it harder for young people and students to register to vote, fearing a blanket ban on registering at two addresses could disenfranchise those who need to be registered in two places due to work or study.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, died by suicide in prison. He played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers in the 1990s. After his NFL career, he had legal troubles and was convicted of assault for driving into a group of teenagers and for assaulting a former girlfriend. He was serving a sentence of more than 30 years for these crimes when he was accused of killing his cellmate. A judge ruled there was enough evidence to try him for the murder of Damion Soward, 37. Phillips was placed in solitary confinement after the accusation. His former coach, Tom Osborne, noted that despite his intelligence and some good qualities, Phillips struggled with anger issues and couldn't overcome the demons in his life.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram, was promoted to lance corporal by Brigadier Andrew Williams during an event in Chester. This promotion was given for "good behavior" and marks the 30th ram in a lineage dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century. The first Private Derby joined the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot in 1858, and Lance Corporal Derby XXX, who joined in February 2014, has participated in various public events, including switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League quarter-finals, with Dejan Lovren scoring the winning goal in injury time. The match was played at Anfield and featured intense emotion, drama, and excitement, with Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp and Dortmund's former coach Thomas Tuchel present. The game was reminiscent of Liverpool's 2005 Champions League win against AC Milan, where they came back from a 3-0 deficit to win. Liverpool needed three goals after Dortmund took a 2-0 lead, and they managed to turn the game around with goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, and Mamadou Sakho, before Lovren's late winner. The atmosphere was electric, with Liverpool fans singing "You'll Never Walk Alone" and observing a minute's silence for the 27th anniversary of the Hillsborough disaster. The victory puts Liverpool into the semi-finals of the Europa League, where they will face another strong team, and it also increases their chances of returning to the Champions League. Klopp has already left a strong impression on his players and the fans, with Liverpool showing a fighting spirit and determination to overcome adversity.

The UK government, led by Brexit Secretary David Davis, met with the devolved administrations of Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland to discuss Brexit negotiations. Davis emphasized the importance of a transparent and collaborative approach, promising regular meetings to share analysis and allow the devolved governments to voice their views. Michael Russell, Scotland's Brexit minister, expressed concern over the lack of clarity regarding the UK government's strategic intentions on single market and customs union membership. He stressed the importance of single market access for Scotland's economy and criticized the UK government for not providing enough transparency. The Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court over the Article 50 triggering process.

The passage discusses a group of cloned sheep, including four identical to Dolly the sheep, who are being closely monitored for signs of aging and disease. The study aims to determine if cloned animals age prematurely or develop age-related diseases more frequently than naturally born animals. The sheep undergo regular physical examinations and tests, such as joint X-rays and MRI scans, to assess their health. The findings could have significant implications for the future of cloning, as they seek to answer whether the cloning process affects the animals' longevity and health.

The passage discusses the win of Shutter Speed in the Musidora Stakes, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters. The trainer, John Gosden, is considering Chantilly for her next race instead of the Epsom Oaks, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are strong contenders. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas, ahead of Magical Memory and Comicas. Shutter Speed's victory was her fifth for Gosden and Dettori, and they noted the soft ground made it challenging for her. Gosden is uncertain about running Cracksman in the Dante Stakes due to the condition of the track and the short preparation time for the Derby.

The pound sterling experienced fluctuations against the dollar, euro, and yen, with a notable decline against the euro and yen. The volatility index reached levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis, reflecting investor uncertainty about the outcome of the Brexit referendum. The Leave campaign suggested the pound's movements were merely reverting to March levels. Sterling was down against the dollar and euro, and weakened against the yen. The currency's volatility is expected to increase as the referendum approaches, with analysts predicting further fluctuations. The economic impact of Brexit is also causing concern, leading to falls in Asian stock markets. The FTSE 100 closed down 1.1% on the day, with Lloyds Banking Group experiencing the largest drop. Nigel Farage, a pro-Leave campaigner, argued that the pound had strengthened since March and that a weaker pound could benefit UK exporters.

The passage discusses AFC Wimbledon, known as 'The Iron', who are currently sixth in the National League and narrowly missing the play-off spots. After a long journey, they conceded a goal early in the match against Barrow, who extended their unbeaten run to nine games with the win. Despite Braintree's losing streak now being three games, manager Neal Ardley Cowley remains optimistic about the team's performance and the challenges they face as a part-time team.

The passage discusses a shift in planning powers in Northern Ireland, where councils will gain the authority to make planning decisions instead of the Planning Service. This change, set to take effect in April 2015, is seen by some as a democratization of the planning system, offering councils the chance to develop community and development plans. However, there are concerns about the ability of politicians to handle these responsibilities effectively and fairly, given past issues with discrimination and potential for favoritism towards certain communities or developers. The passage also highlights the need for a strict code of conduct and transparency to prevent corruption and ensure fairness. Additionally, it raises the issue of political donations and the call for greater transparency in this area to prevent undue influence on planning decisions.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun, suffering injuries that required the amputation of her left back leg. The incident occurred in a housing estate in Winchburgh on March 14. The cat's owner, Sarah Nisbett, expressed concern about the safety of children in the area and the cruelty of the act. The Scottish SPCA is investigating and has called for the licensing of air weapons to prevent such incidents. The Scottish government previously held a consultation on air weapon licensing, which received a majority of negative responses, but the SPCA still advocates for stricter regulations to prevent irresponsible use of air guns.

Christian Benteke has joined Liverpool from Aston Villa for £32.5m, becoming their second most expensive signing. The 24-year-old Belgian striker, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, signed a long-term contract with Liverpool. The move comes after Liverpool sold Raheem Sterling to Manchester City for £49m and follows the acquisition of other forwards like Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino. Benteke's arrival is seen as an effort to strengthen Liverpool's attack, which struggled last season with the absence of key players like Daniel Sturridge and the departure of Luis Suarez. Manager Brendan Rodgers aims to revive the Reds' attack with Benteke, who missed the 2014 World Cup due to an Achilles tendon injury but returned to form last season with Villa. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert believes Benteke will do well at Liverpool, while former Liverpool striker John Aldridge is optimistic about the team's attacking prospects with Benteke leading the line.

The study by the charity Tablets for Schools found that while tablet computers are increasingly used in UK schools, there is no clear evidence that they improve academic results. The research, conducted by Barbie Clarke of the Family, Kids and Youth research group, surveyed 671 schools and found that 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools use tablets to some extent. In 9% of schools, every pupil has their own tablet. The study highlights that while head teachers report a positive impact on motivation and family involvement, it is not possible to definitively link tablet use to improved academic outcomes. The report also notes that tablets are more prevalent in academy schools and that their use is expected to grow. A separate study suggests that touch-screen computers are particularly beneficial for boys and poorer pupils in learning to read. The findings underscore the pervasive role of online technology in the lives of young people, with many pupils reporting internet addiction and taking devices to bed for social media and video consumption.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing children's lives from the 1880s to the 1990s. The images provide a social history of Liverpool, showing changes in childhood experiences and marking special occasions. The oldest photo dates back to 1887, showing the Rollo children in fancy dress. Another image depicts a young maid, highlighting child labor. Curator Kay Jones selected the photos from National Museums Liverpool's collections, aiming to showcase both joyful and challenging aspects of childhood. The exhibition runs until September 25.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow to join their National League rivals on a mutual consent basis. He has experience with clubs including Aldershot and Exeter, and has played in Italy. He could make his debut against his former club on February 18. Meanwhile, 21-year-old striker Keating is joining Exeter City after being recommended by Micky Adams to manager Kevin Nicholson. Keating has played for various Irish clubs and his move is subject to international clearance. Nicholson sees Anderson as a valuable addition due to his leadership qualities, while Keating is described as young, hungry, and a bit raw in his skills. Exeter City, currently four points above the relegation zone, have struggled recently with only one win in their last six games.

The new Bolivian law permits 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's poverty. It imposes harsher penalties for violence against children, including 30 years in jail for child homicide. The law was signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales, who aimed to balance local needs with international treaties. The law is intended to help eradicate poverty, despite the International Labour Organization's stance that children under 15 should not work, allowing a minimum age of 14 for developing countries. Bolivia has over 500,000 children working to support their families, often in harsh conditions.

Actress Rosie O'Donnell, 50, had a "widow maker" heart attack after experiencing sudden nausea and chest pain. She did not call emergency services but instead took aspirin and visited a cardiologist the next day, who found a 99% blockage in an artery and inserted a stent. O'Donnell urges women to recognize heart attack symptoms and to call 911 if they suspect they are having one. She recently hosted The Rosie Show, which was canceled due to low ratings.

A 15-year-old boy named Che Labastide-Wellington was stabbed and killed in an alleyway near Belvedere Way, Kenton, after a party on Saturday night. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed but is in stable condition. Police believe Che was not involved in an earlier altercation with a group denied entry to the party but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and three boys aged 15, 16, and 14 have been arrested in connection with the incident.

The passage discusses Denmark's response to poor cancer survival rates over 15 years ago, which led to the implementation of a new diagnostic approach. The changes included establishing three routes for patient diagnosis: fast-track for patients with alarming symptoms, diagnosis centers for those with unclear symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. These changes resulted in better organization and quicker diagnosis, leading to improved survival rates and potentially offering lessons for countries like Wales with similar healthcare systems.

The new body, Powys council, will take over from the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) in regulating estate agents. It will issue warnings and banning orders for dishonest or unlawful practices. The council won a competitive bid for the role and will receive £170,000 annually. Complaints will initially go to local trading standards departments, but they will refer cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act to Powys. James Munro, leading the new team, hopes this role will lead to more outside contracts for Powys in the future.

The NHS is considering retraining nurses and other health workers to fill gaps left by shortages of doctors, following a report by the Nuffield Trust. The report highlights examples where nurses and pharmacists are already performing tasks typically done by doctors. While NHS Employers sees potential in reshaping the workforce, unions warn against using this as a quick fix for NHS problems. They stress the need for adequate funding for training and express concerns that such measures should not compromise the quality of doctor training.

A collision on the Lower Bristol Road in Bath outside the First depot at 03:00 GMT led to the closure of the A36 road until 14:00 GMT. This caused significant disruption and delays during rush hour. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the crash. First Bus services were affected, with some resuming a normal schedule by midday, but a full recovery to normal operations was expected to take a few more hours. Managing Director James Freeman expressed gratitude for the public's support and the extra efforts of staff in managing the situation.

The Swansea tidal lagoon project is estimated to cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout deaths annually as they migrate. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputes these figures, claiming they lack a clear scientific basis and that NRW refused to share its methodology for calculating them. TLP's own experts' computer modeling suggests a worst-case scenario of 2% fish mortality. NRW, the regulator, asserts that its figures are based on the best available evidence and have been reviewed by independent experts. The Welsh Government supports the project but seeks clarity on the UK government's position.

The Northern Ireland government announced the creation of a new agri-food marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, to boost the sector's marketing efforts. The new body will be led by the industry and is expected to enhance coordination and strategic direction for marketing activities across both the public and private sectors. The move is seen as crucial for the agri-food industry, which employs nearly 100,000 people in various roles including farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill supports the initiative but notes that it could affect the work of other organizations, including her own department. Discussions with the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) will be necessary to finalize the plans.

On Saturday, the public is invited to plant 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, organized by the Woodland Trust. This is part of a four-year project to plant millions of native UK trees to commemorate WW1 casualties, with 40,000 trees dedicated to the Irish who died in the conflict. The event aims to create a woodland with wildflowers and a habitat for wildlife, encouraging reflection and relaxation for future visitors. The Woodland Trust provides the saplings, and participants are advised to wear appropriate footwear. The event is located near Derry city and parking is limited.

Hilary Mantel's novel "Someone Else's Skin" won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award at the Harrogate Crime Writing Festival. The book, which tackles domestic violence and so-called honor crimes, features Det Insp Marnie Rome and is the first in a series. The novel was praised for its atmosphere and handling of the subject matter. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution award for her 23-year career and creation of the strong female protagonist, VI Warshawski, who has influenced crime fiction with her action hero-like qualities. Paretsky also founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers.

Core pieces of information: 
1. Santner, a 24-year-old cricketer, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016.
2. Steve Rhodes, Worcestershire's director of cricket, believes Santner has unfinished business with the county due to his injury.
3. Rhodes mentions that Santner's injury was a massive blow to their hopes of qualifying for something unspecified.
4. Santner made his Test debut in 2015 and will rejoin the Rapids after the ICC Trophy in June.
5. Santner enjoyed his time at Worcestershire and is looking forward to returning next summer to contribute with bat and ball.
6. In August 2017, Worcestershire signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old man, was unlawfully killed in 2008 when he was hit by a speeding car on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev while trying to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was not with him at the time of the incident; she had returned to a restaurant to retrieve a missing glove. The coroner at the inquest, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, concluded that Pring's guard was down due to inebriation and that the car involved had stolen license plates and did not brake or stop. The coroner found the evidence overwhelming and concluded that Pring was unlawfully killed. The case highlights the difficulties in investigating a death abroad and the distress experienced by his family. The inquest revealed that Ms. Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger than her husband, tried to claim his assets shortly after his death and sold his possessions. She was also alleged to have had an affair with a Ukrainian man and was suspected by his family of involvement in his death to inherit his money and property. Ms. Ziuzina did not attend the inquest, despite efforts to have her present. The Ukrainian police initially

Charlie, a three-year-old boy from Merseyside, needs to return to Seattle, America for experimental T-Cell Therapy treatment due to the failure of his previous transplant. His mother, Sophie Fearns, expressed gratitude for an anonymous donor who has paid for his treatment, which was previously unaffordable for the family. The treatment will commence as soon as Charlie receives financial clearance from the hospital.

Apple has introduced a two-step verification process for iCloud accounts to prevent unauthorized access to users' data. The new feature requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or via SMS when logging into iCloud from a new device for the first time. This step is optional but recommended by Apple to enhance account security. The change comes in response to recent hacks where intimate photos of celebrities were stolen from iCloud. Apple's move is designed to prevent the use of third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, which was previously able to bypass two-step verification to access iCloud backups. However, there are concerns about the recovery key, which if lost, could lead to permanent data loss. Security experts suggest that two-factor authentication should be the default setting for all tech companies to enhance account security.

Former I'm A Celebrity contestant and footballer Darryn Wright is in talks to buy 20% of Billericay Town FC and become a club director. The finer details of the deal are yet to be disclosed. Billericay are currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a playoff spot. The club has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has expressed willingness to invest £10,000 a week. They have also signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Sports Direct founder Mike Ashley has been asked to give evidence to a parliamentary committee about the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation. The Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, chaired by Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, has invited Ashley to a meeting at the company's Shirebrook base. Ashley has been given until 21 March to respond to the invitation, which was sent after a letter from Wright. The letter states that the committee will keep the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage under review. The committee has offered several dates for the meeting, but Ashley has not accepted any of them. If he fails to agree to attend, the committee reserves the right to take the matter further, including seeking the support of the House of Commons in respect of any complaint of contempt.

The report "Putin. War" was completed by associates of a murdered opposition politician, Ilya Yashin, to accuse President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for personal gain. The report, based on existing media reports and new evidence, details the involvement of Russian soldiers and equipment in the conflict, contradicting Russia's claim that Russians in Ukraine are "volunteers." The report includes testimonies from Russian veterans and evidence of financial incentives for volunteers. Boris Nemtsov, who began the report, was assassinated before its completion, and his associates are now seeking donations to publish and distribute it. Despite the availability of information on Russia's involvement in Ukraine, the report faces challenges due to fear among publishers and a divided public opinion within Russia. The opposition believes the report will expose Putin's manipulation of the conflict to boost his popularity, which has been successful despite earlier critical reports by Nemtsov that failed to mobilize significant protest.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, died from head injuries at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire. He was 34 and from Wath-Upon-Dearn, Rotherham. Two people, a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman, were arrested in Sheffield in connection with his death and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the friction between the Welsh and UK governments regarding the Brexit process, particularly concerning the Article 50 letter. First Minister Carwyn Jones expressed dissatisfaction with not being consulted on the letter's drafting, despite having general discussions with Prime Minister Theresa May. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered that the UK government must act in the interests of the whole UK, mentioning that Wales was mentioned in the letter. The letter promises consultation on the return of powers from the EU, with the expectation of increased decision-making power for devolved administrations. However, the specific powers and accompanying funding remain unclear. The passage also touches on the political implications and potential shifts in power and funding post-Brexit, with concerns raised by Carwyn Jones about the financial aspect of devolved powers.

Two cars were damaged in an incident involving attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The attack occurred on Friday night in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing, suggesting that children may have been involved in the incident.

Dov Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was fired last year due to employee complaints and accusations of financial misconduct. He has since filed a defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. In response, the company has filed a lawsuit in San Francisco, alleging that Charney sent inappropriate emails to female employees and made racially derogatory comments. The board of American Apparel states that Charney violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies and that his behavior makes him unemployable. The court has granted a restraining order against Charney, preventing him from making negative statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The British men's basketball team will play Greece at the Copper Box in London on 24 June. This game serves as a preparation for EuroBasket 2017, with the tournament starting in September. The match will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app from 17:30 to 19:30 BST. Three Greek players who played in the earlier match in Greece will be absent, giving GB a chance for revenge. Guard Teddy Okereafor, a local from Stratford, is excited about the game and believes it will help the team prepare for the European competition. The game is the last home match before the team travels to a tournament in Poland.

The passage discusses the introduction of the iPhone in 2007 by Apple, marking a significant shift in how people interacted with mobile technology. Before the iPhone, phones were primarily used for making calls. However, Steve Jobs' unveiling of the iPhone introduced a device that was not only a phone but also a powerful computer, camera, and internet device, all in one. The author recalls being skeptical about the iPhone's revolutionary potential at the time but now acknowledges its transformative impact on various industries, particularly photography. The iPhone's user-friendly interface made it accessible and appealing to a broad audience, changing the way people communicated, shared content, and conducted daily activities. The passage concludes by recognizing the iPhone's role in starting the mobile connected era and highlights the ongoing innovation by companies like Amazon and Google in the field of artificial intelligence.

The RSPCA has confirmed that several cats in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting antifreeze. The most recent victim, seven-month-old Meereen, died on Monday. Her owner, Adria Pearce, is devastated. Another cat died two weeks ago, and three others died in the last seven days. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock is concerned and urges people to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially since it's the time of year when antifreeze is used in cars.

The passage discusses the lack of public protests in Greece despite the Syriza government's agreement to implement more austerity and liberalization measures under pressure from creditors. It notes that while Greece's tourism industry is thriving, possibly due to the desire to visit during a potential euro break-up or as a safer alternative to regions affected by ISIS, the Greek people are not demonstrating against the new austerity measures. The calm is seen as possibly preceding a revelation of the concessions made by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras in exchange for a €86bn bailout. The passage also highlights Tsipras' popularity despite his failure to end fiscal austerity and the additional monetary austerity caused by the continued partial closure of banks. The situation is described as a "vicious economic squeeze" that will likely further impoverish Greeks. The passage concludes that for the bailout to succeed, creditors must show leniency in debt relief, avoiding triumphalism and instead offering a genuine path to recovery.

Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell in "EastEnders," is returning for a brief stint to reunite with his on-screen family as his character comes back to Albert Square to say goodbye to his mother, Peggy, who is dying of cancer. The return is set to air in emotional scenes during the spring. Grant Mitchell is described as an EastEnders legend, known for his tumultuous relationships with his brother Phil and his ex-wife Sharon.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon was found guilty of murdering Alice Ruggles last October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately suspected Dhillon when informed of her death. They expressed guilt for not taking earlier warnings more seriously, particularly a phone call from their other daughter, Emma, who had sensed the danger. In response to the tragedy, Alice's parents have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking and to honor their daughter's memory as a vibrant and cheerful person. Dhillon was sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The French energy firm EDF has approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant in Somerset. The government, however, will "consider carefully" before backing the project, following comments from Business Secretary Greg Clark. EDF's CEO Vincent de Rivaz has cancelled a visit to the site due to the government's review. Critics warn of environmental damage, potential cost escalations, and the involvement of foreign governments, including China, which is providing one-third of the funding. The project has faced numerous delays and concerns over EDF's financial capacity. The government's decision to review the project is seen as a potential policy shift and a blow to the nuclear sector. The plant is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity and has been subject to significant investment and construction efforts. Environmentalists and some industry figures urge a swift decision to avoid energy supply issues and to meet climate commitments.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person your spouse has committed adultery with, which family lawyers fear could increase conflict. They argue that naming the third party is generally unnecessary and can lead to more complications. The Ministry of Justice states that while it has always been possible to name the third party, there is no obligation to do so. The updated form aims to make the divorce process more user-friendly, but the inclusion of the box for the adulterer's name may encourage more people to name them, despite the guidance suggesting it is not normally necessary. Family lawyers express concern that naming the third party could lead to increased conflict and legal costs.

The core pieces of information from the passage are:

1. Britain is the world's third largest importer of wood.
2. There is a concern that commercial forests in Wales are being lost, with 16,000 hectares (40,000 acres) needing replanting since 2001.
3. The forestry industry is estimated to contribute more than £450m annually to the Welsh economy.
4. There is a conflict between commercial forestry and environmental policy, with a preference for native, broadleaf species and better access for recreation.
5. Half of the woodland in Wales is managed by Natural Resources Wales, and the other half by private companies.
6. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social benefits in forestry development.
7. The Glastir scheme encourages farmers and landowners to plant woodland.
8. The Welsh government's Woodlands for Wales strategy focuses on high-quality woodlands that benefit the environment, society, and the economy.
9. Martin Bishop of Confor believes the focus on environmental aspects overshadows the importance of commercial forestry.
10. There is a need to plant 20,000 hectares of woodland annually to meet ministerial targets,

A boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge. Emergency services were called to Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at 16:40. The boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow.

The passage describes the presentation of the Ushakov medals to veterans of the Arctic Convoys by Capt Oleg Kornienko. Able Seaman Charles Lewis, 91, from Calmore, Hampshire, received the medal and expressed that he did not see himself as a hero, but rather as someone who did his part in the war effort. The convoys, which took place during World War II, were dangerous missions from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union. They faced constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, as well as harsh weather conditions. The convoys were crucial in supporting the Soviet Union's fight against Germany on the Eastern Front. The British Government initially did not allow the veterans to receive the Russian medal due to Foreign Office rules, but an exception was made in 2013, and the first medals were presented by President Vladimir Putin during his visit to London. The Ushakov medal is awarded for courage in defending Russia or its interests.

The passage discusses the HM Inspectorate of Probation's findings regarding unpaid work (community payback) sentences in England and Wales. The report highlights issues such as delays in starting unpaid work, low completion rates, and the failure to enforce attendance. It notes that offenders are often not completing their required hours and that the scheme lacks focus on rehabilitation. The report makes 15 recommendations for improvement, including better organization and matching unpaid work to the offender's circumstances. The Ministry of Justice agrees with the report's findings and is taking action to implement the recommendations to improve the effectiveness of community payback sentences.

The passage discusses how comedian Russell Brand is accused of hypocrisy by The Sun newspaper for advocating for economic and political revolution to help poorer people while living in a luxury home. The article mentions Brand's response to a reporter's question about his rent, calling the journalist "snide" and walking off. The passage also includes Brand's past statements defending himself against the hypocrisy charge, emphasizing the need for personal and systemic change.

The passage describes J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur known for his controversial and groundbreaking work in genomics. Initially vilified by the scientific community for his competitive approach to mapping the human genome, Venter has made significant contributions to the field, speeding up the process of genomic research. He has been criticized for his self-assured statements about his achievements and his wealth, but his innovations have been undeniable.

Venter's career transitioned from a lackluster academic start to a focus on medical research after his experiences in the Vietnam War. He excelled in research rather than medical practice and was pivotal in the early days of molecular biology. His introduction of automated decoding machines and his shift to studying RNA accelerated gene sequencing.

His most notable achievements include:

1. The first complete genome sequence of a free-living organism, Haemophilus influenzae.
2. The formation of Celera Genomics to compete with the public Human Genome Project, leading to the simultaneous publication of the human genome sequence in 2001.
3. The establishment of the J. Craig Venter Institute, which aimed to create the first synthetic life form.

The creation of Synthia, the synthetic life

The passage discusses a survey conducted by England's School Food Trust, which found that school lunches are instrumental in introducing children to new foods that they do not typically eat at home. Four out of five children who ate school lunches tried new foods there. Half of the parents surveyed reported that their children requested these new foods to be prepared at home as well. The survey involved about 1,000 parents, and it highlighted that carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables among children, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The research was prompted by concerns from parents who believed their children were too fussy to eat school lunches. Rob Rees, the Trust chairman, emphasized the role of school meals in expanding children's diets. Carrie Longton, co-founder of Mumsnet, noted that school meals have improved and that peer pressure can encourage children to eat more healthily at school. The article also mentions that school meals in England must adhere to strict nutritional guidelines and that more primary school children than secondary school children eat school lunches. In Scotland, the percentage of children eating school lunches is higher at about 46%.

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker, joined Juventus in 2014 from Real Madrid. He has scored 27 goals for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. Morata has been linked with Arsenal and Chelsea but has an option for Real Madrid to buy him back for up to 30m euros. He has scored three times for Spain at Euro 2016 and played in back-to-back Champions League finals. Morata made his Real Madrid debut at 18 and scored 10 goals for them.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, played for Nottingham Forest in the Championship. He previously had spells with Celtic, Preston North End, and Notts County. He was released from Forest in May 2014 and has been without a team since then.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is selling its loss-making US food chain Fresh & Easy to Yucaipa Companies, a private equity firm. Around 4,000 out of 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business. Tesco will provide an 80 million pound loan to the new business, which will operate in California, Nevada, and Arizona. The remaining 50 Fresh & Easy stores will be closed. The disposal of Fresh & Easy is expected to cost Tesco 150 million pounds, but part of this is a loan that may be repaid, and Tesco has the option to buy a stake if Yucaipa makes the business profitable.

The passage discusses a martial artist who initially faced racial abuse but decided to represent Great Britain instead of France. He is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. The passage also mentions a guide on how to get into martial arts.

The core pieces of information from the passage are:

1. In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields in the Mont Blanc region covered about 375 sq km.
2. By the late 2000s, this area had reduced to approximately 275 sq km.
3. The research was presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting.
4. The findings mirror similar retreats in other sectors of the Alps.
5. The new French Alps glaciers inventory was conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues.
6. The inventory assessed roughly 600 glaciers in various massifs, including Mont Blanc.
7. The team used map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs for their study.
8. Manual inspection was necessary to correct automatic delineation errors due to debris cover and shadows.
9. The previous inventory from the 1970s found a total ice area of about 375 sq km.
10. By 1985-86, the ice area had decreased to about 340 sq km.
11. Since then, the retreat has accelerated, with the ice area reduced to about 275 sq km in the late 2

Scotland women's national football team are aiming to reach their first major tournament finals. They have won all five qualifiers so far and host Iceland on Friday, knowing victory would all but secure their place. The team has previously missed out on major competitions after play-off losses. The match against Iceland is crucial as both teams are unbeaten and top the group. Scotland's players are spread across various top leagues, including England, Sweden, and the US, which is believed to enhance their performance as a national team. Bayern Munich forward Christie Murray, who was born in Perth, has experienced the success of playing in the German Bundesliga and mingling with male football stars like Franck Ribery and Arjen Robben. The match against Iceland is seen as a pivotal game that could determine the group winners and potentially secure Scotland's place in the finals without the need for a play-off.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence blogger and former computer games reviewer, was arrested in the west of England on Friday on suspicion of online harassment. The complaint came from a woman in south London, alleging harassment over a two-year period. The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating an allegation of online harassment made by a woman in her 30s. Mr. Campbell, who was released on bail, insists the allegations concern some tweets and are not threatening. He criticized the media for using innuendo to encourage speculation. The tweets in question remain publicly visible and no further action has been taken until mid-September.

PETA wants to replace the traditional Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness with a modern, animal-friendly version featuring a fish and the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." The original Jolly Fisherman poster was created in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway to promote Skegness as a seaside destination. PETA argues that the Jolly Fisherman evokes images of cruelty to animals, while the mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, believes the mascot is loved by the community and does not represent animal cruelty. The town council will consider PETA's suggestion, but Macey suggests that if the mascot is not problematic, there is no need for change.

Scotland beat Georgia 38-11 in a Six Nations match at Murrayfield. Scotland scored six tries, with Tommy Seymour, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg (twice), Hamish Watson and Ali Price crossing the line. Vasil Lobzhanidze scored two tries for Georgia. Greig Laidlaw converted four of Scotland's tries and kicked a penalty. Scotland dominated possession and territory in the first half, leading 24-11 at halftime. Georgia improved in the second half, scoring a try from a powerful scrum, but Scotland responded with a late try from Hogg. Scotland's Vern Cotter praised his team's approach and management of the game.

Widnes Vikings defeated Castleford Tigers 38-24 in a rugby league match. Widnes scored tries through Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge in the first half, leading 14-6 at halftime. Paddy Flynn scored two tries for Castleford, but Widnes extended their lead with tries from Lloyd White (2) and Joe Mellor. Despite Castleford scoring three tries in quick succession, Widnes held on for the win. The victory moved Widnes above Wakefield in the league standings, while Castleford remained in sixth place, one point ahead of Widnes. Castleford's loss was their fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti citizen, was released from the US detention facility at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, after a review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat." He was detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies. His release comes after a July decision by the Periodic Review Board that his continued detention was not necessary for US security. Despite his release, he faces mandatory rehabilitation in Kuwait.
