His mother used to get lost when left alone, and since his father passed away earlier this year, Lu has no one else to care for her. His wife works in a different city, and his son is still in school. The journey to work takes an hour, and his employer, a bank, has provided a room for his mother. Lu feels it is his duty to care for his mother as she devoted her life to caring for her children. He says, "I was an apple in my mum's eye, and now she's my apple."

The study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found that heavy drinking among Americans rose by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, with women's drinking habits changing significantly and driving the increase. Binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion at least once in the past month. The study tracked drinking patterns at the county level and found that Madison County, Idaho, had the lowest binge drinking rate in 2012 at 6%, while Menominee, Wisconsin, had the highest at 36%. The increase in binge drinking doesn't surprise addiction treatment professionals who have seen more people seeking help for alcoholism in recent years. Public health experts attribute the rise in drinking to changing social norms, increased affordability of alcohol due to lower taxes and weaker alcohol control policies, and more aggressive alcohol advertising. The study also noted that the cost of excessive drinking in the US was estimated at more than $220 billion per year, and 88,600 deaths were attributed to alcohol in 2010.

The United Nations World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that doctors are performing caesarean sections too frequently, putting the health of women and their babies at risk. The WHO states that caesarean sections should only be performed when medically necessary, as they can lead to infections and even death. The rate of caesarean sections in England has more than doubled since the early 1990s, with over a quarter of women now having the procedure. The WHO advises that the ideal rate should be between 10% and 15% due to the associated risks and costs. Planned caesareans cost the NHS significantly more than natural births. The WHO's statement contradicts the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines, which allow for caesareans in cases of severe childbirth anxiety (tokophobia) and other non-medical reasons. The WHO emphasizes that doctors are underestimating the risks of caesarean sections, which can cause complications and divert resources from other patients.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after Mark Conklin found her living in his $800,000 summer home on Martha's Vineyard. Filkins claimed ownership of the house and fled in a gray Nissan pickup when Conklin called the police. She was later arrested after attempting to re-enter the property. The police report indicates that Filkins had broken a glass window and covered it with a blanket. She is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Items missing from the home include furniture, kitchenware, and a painting. The police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department, as they are considered victims in the case.

A lost iPhone was returned to its owner, Bella Crooke from Melbourne, after police officers from Albury, on the NSW-Victoria border, posted photos and messages on her Facebook page. The phone was handed in on Sunday morning, and the officers, realizing it was unlocked, used it to post selfies and humorous messages to locate Bella. They reassured her that the phone was safe and even joked about charging the battery. When Bella arrived to collect her phone, she didn't have to identify herself as the officers recognized her from the Facebook posts. She praised the officers for their humor and efficiency in reuniting her with her lost phone, and she has now secured her phone with a password.

A five-day-old baby hippo was killed in a fight between two adult hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa. The helpless calf was caught in the crossfire, thrown into the air, and dragged along the water's surface before succumbing to its injuries hours later. The mother hippo watched in horror but chose to stay with her herd, likely believing it safer for her. Stacey Farrell, a tour operator, witnessed the tragic event and described the mother's futile attempts to save her calf.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is being sold for £575,000, which is significantly lower than the average price for such properties in the area. However, the catch is that the lease only has three years remaining. This means that the cost works out to approximately £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, which is roughly the rental price for a similar property. If a buyer decides to extend the lease, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The apartment, located in Egerton Place, is described as bright and well-proportioned with 1,990 sq/ft of space, including three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, and a utility room, along with parking and a communal garden. The property is in need of renovation and is being sold by Russell Simpson. If modernized, it could fetch between £2.75 million and £3 million per square foot. The current freeholder is believed to be the Welcome Trust, and extending the lease to 90 years could cost between £3.35 million and £4.5 million. The estate was built in 1893 and has housed residents of high status, including government officials and the

Starbucks experienced a computer outage on Friday evening affecting 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing registers to malfunction and leading baristas to give away free drinks. The issue, which began in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast, was resolved overnight. Starbucks stated that stores would open as usual on Saturday, and the outage was due to a failure during a daily system refresh. The incident led to a mix of customer satisfaction and inconvenience as some stores closed early to avoid giving away products for free. Despite the technical hiccup, Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings the day before the outage.

Terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, including locations in Ceridigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. The individuals involved in these activities blend into the community with seemingly ordinary activities but have an ulterior motive. The issue of terrorism is not confined to large cities, as incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales can be traced back to 1998 when hate preacher Abu Hamza sent a group to train in the Brecon Beacons. The Brecon Beacons, known for its rugged terrain used for military training, including by elite forces like the SAS, was one of several locations used by the British military. In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed white water rafting in Bala, North Wales. Additionally, in 2010, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff were arrested for plotting a Mumbai-style attack. Michael Adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, is understood to have studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder, which was set up by Iraqi clerics. Detective Constable Gareth Jones

An omura's whale, a species thought to be extinct, was found washed up on a remote beach in Western Australia after Cyclone Olwyn. This is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The 5.68m juvenile female was initially difficult to identify, but DNA profiling confirmed it was an omura's whale. The species is known for its sleek body and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. Very little is known about omura's whales, and this discovery is significant for scientists studying the species, as they are typically found in tropical and subtropical waters of Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and potential display in museums.

The passage discusses the absurdity of judging a female presidential candidate's ability based on hormones, contrasting it with historical male leaders whose decisions were influenced by testosterone. It highlights the gender bias women face in leadership roles, citing studies that show women leaders are less likely to take unnecessary risks. The piece emphasizes the need for a serious discussion about ending gender bias, noting that despite women's achievements and outnumbering men in education, they still face significant barriers in leadership. The article concludes by stating that gender equality benefits everyone, citing economic and social advantages, and ends with a correction regarding Canada's first female prime minister.

actor robert hardy, 89, is selling his extensive collection of antiques, including a detailed diorama of the battle of agincourt, furniture, paintings, swords, and a longbow, at a £100,000 auction. The collection reflects his interests in classic literature and military history. He studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis at Oxford and is an expert on the medieval longbow. The auction, taking place this Saturday at Dominic Winter in Gloucestershire, includes 238 lots and is a result of his decision to downsize his home. Mr. Hardy, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small," "The Gathering Storm," and "Harry Potter," expressed sadness at parting with his collection but hopes it brings joy to new owners.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man, is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the day his mother's body was found at their shared home in Winter Garden. Authorities suspect foul play in her death. Shemansky, who has a history of bipolar mental illness and attempted suicide, was on parole for battery on law enforcement and had a domestic violence injunction against him from his estranged wife. He is believed to have asked for water at the trailer park office shortly after the murder and is considered armed and dangerous. His estranged wife is preparing for his potential arrival at her home, and anyone with information on his whereabouts is urged to contact the police.

Eugene, United States, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships, bypassing the usual bidding process due to a perceived 'unique strategic opportunity' to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 championships, which went to Doha, Qatar. The decision was influenced by the city's presentation and the support from public authorities, the private sector, the US Olympic Committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public. This decision, similar to the one made for the 2007 championships in Osaka, Japan, is seen as a strategic move to expand the sport's reach globally.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model from Gillingham, Kent, targeted and befriended professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, at a London casino. She used her looks to gain his attention and he showered her with gifts, cash, and trips to fancy restaurants. After gaining his trust, Granger left Hassan's flat unlocked so her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and his accomplice Nicholas Chandler could enter and attack him. The two men tied up Hassan, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home in search of his hidden winnings. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter by a majority verdict and sentenced to 16 years in prison. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 36 years. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked." Granger's defense claimed she was in love with Jackson and fell in with his desires, but the judge stated she was deceitful from the outset and lost her sense and compassion. The trio was also convicted of robbery, conspiracy to falsely imprison, and plotting to rob casino employees.

Cesc Fabregas, a midfielder for Chelsea, has been struggling with his form during the second half of the season. Despite starting the season strongly, with a promising partnership with Diego Costa and impressive performances, his form has dipped significantly. He was notably one of the worst players in Spain's 2-0 loss to Holland on Tuesday. Fabregas has been criticized for his recent performances, with Spanish media giving him low ratings. His stats have shown a decline, particularly in assists, which had him on track to break Thierry Henry's Premier League record. However, with only one assist in his last five games, that record now seems out of reach. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho will be hoping for a resurgence in Fabregas's form as the team aims to secure the Premier League title. The midfielder's recent assist to Diego Costa against Hull City may be a sign of improvement.

West Ham United is considering signing 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who has impressed during a trial period with the club's academy. Beckford has also attracted interest from Belgian clubs and is considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean. Meanwhile, West Ham has announced that season tickets for their move to the Olympic Stadium for the 2016-17 season will start at £289, aiming to have the lowest pricing strategy among Barclays Premier League clubs to fill the 54,000-seat stadium.

Police have halted an investigation into a violent assault on a huntsman despite having substantial evidence, including video footage and car registration numbers of suspected attackers. The victim, Mike Lane, 40, who was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, criticized the police for not making more effort to pursue the case. The attack occurred in January when Mr. Lane and other hunt members were pursuing an artificial scent, not a fox. Despite providing evidence to the police, including a video of the incident and names of suspects, the investigation was closed due to insufficient evidence. The victim suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss as a result of the attack. The assailant's face was captured on video, but no arrests have been made. Hunt supporters are dismayed by the police's decision, and the Countryside Alliance is advocating for a ban on saboteurs wearing face coverings to aid in bringing criminals to justice. Wiltshire Police confirmed the investigation was halted pending new evidence but expressed hope that the case could be reopened if additional information emerges.

Adam Gadahn, a U.S. citizen who joined al-Qaeda and became one of its prominent propagandists, was killed in January 2015 in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation. He was born in 1978 and converted to Islam in 1995, moving to Pakistan three years later. Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al-Qaeda. He appeared in numerous videos for the terrorist group, criticizing U.S. leaders and policies and urging Muslims to carry out lone-wolf attacks within the United States. Gadahn's final video was released in 2014, where he called for the overthrow of governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. He was married and had at least one child.

Mai Zizhuo, a five-year-old Chinese boy, has become an internet sensation for his exceptional basketball skills. He has been playing since the age of two and a half and can dribble two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm. His viral video has garnered him many fans in China, where basketball is popular, and has even drawn comparisons to Yao Ming, the country's most famous NBA player. Netizens are stunned by his talent and some express a desire to start over and dedicate themselves to basketball like Mai has.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the Paedophile Information Exchange, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off is a media pressure group that supports statutory regulation of the press, a stance recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's involvement with Hacked Off is likely to be seen as an embarrassment for the group, given his past association with the Paedophile Information Exchange, which campaigned for the legalization of child sex in the 1970s and 80s and sought to lower the age of consent to ten. O'Carroll was jailed in 1981 for 'corrupting public morals' and was a member of the National Council for Civil Liberties' gay rights sub-committee.

On Thursday, the iconic Bondi Icebergs pool was drained to serve as a unique catwalk for the Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The ten pieces presentation by the lifestyle brand mono featured models showcasing a monochrome collection of ten pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. The show took place in front of a beautiful ocean backdrop and was attended by guests who enjoyed refreshments. The event was held on a warm day and attracted the attention of beachgoers and passersby, creating a unique intersection of fashion and beach culture.

Boxer Amir Khan, from Bolton, took a break from his training to visit a safari park in northern California with his family. They were seen posing with and feeding a white tiger, as well as giraffes and sea lions at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom. Earlier this week, Khan announced he will fight former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent. He had been linked with fights against Kell Brook, Adrien Broner, and Keith Thurman, but chose Algieri.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a Palestinian teenager, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. His name was mistakenly included on an Israeli memorial wall at Mount Herzl, which honors fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. His family and the organization Almagor, which supports terror victims, objected to his inclusion. Almagor described the incident as a rogue attack and not a terror victim. Following complaints, Mohammed Abu Khdeir's name has been removed from the memorial wall and the organization's website.

A young boy, filmed by his California-based father Lionel Hutz, uses his family cat as a pillow by chasing it around the garden to find a resting spot. The cat initially licks its fur, but when the boy lies down on it, the cat quickly moves to another spot. This sequence repeats twice more until the cat, tired of being used as a pillow, goes indoors. Later footage shows the boy and cat reconciled, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia has seen a witness, Robert Kushner, lose his varsity coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past dealing of marijuana. Kushner, 32, is one of more than a dozen former drug dealers testifying against the accused officers. He claimed that during a 2007 arrest, some of the undercover officers stole $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him. Kushner passed a background check when he was hired in 2010 but his past came to light after his testimony. He acknowledged a 2011 arrest and a guilty plea for driving under the influence in 2008, but stated that the 2007 charges were expunged as part of a probationary sentence. He maintains that he has moved past that phase of his life and is remorseful for his past actions. The defense argues that the government's case relies on the testimony of 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in Zhanzhou, Fujian Province, China, injured six people on Monday night. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility following an oil leak, but there was no reported toxic chemical spill. The fire is now under control after more than 600 firefighters were dispatched. The plant, which produces a carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production, had previously been relocated from Xiamen due to public outcry over pollution concerns.

jack grealish, the aston villa teenager and ireland under 21 international, is known for wearing his socks low and using children's shinpads due to superstition. despite referees' warnings, he intends to continue this practice. he made his first premier league start against qpr, which ended in a 3-3 draw, and expressed satisfaction with the opportunity, although he hopes for more starts before the end of the season.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Whitney Houston and Bobby Brown, has "global and irreversible brain damage" according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive. Her condition has not changed for nearly three months, and she has a tracheostomy. The family's statements about her condition have varied, with Bobby Brown claiming she was awake and watching him, while Cissy Houston and an attorney for the family indicating that her condition is irreversible and she is beginning a long rehabilitation process, the quality of which remains uncertain.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup tie with Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeating Sabine Lisicki and Svetlana Kuznetsova winning against Julia Goerges. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with Lisicki's powerful play but managed to save a match point and win 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3. Both players had serving issues, with Pavlyuchenkova committing 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors. Lisicki noted the match was very close and she had a match point, but Pavlyuchenkova played well in the deciding moments. Russia needs one more win out of three matches on Sunday to secure a spot in the final and win their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to brace for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. Meteorologists are concerned about an east coast low similar to the one that caused severe weather last week, with heavy rain expected from Thursday through to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is still dealing with over 4,000 jobs from the 24,196 requests made last week and is worried that more storms will hinder clean-up efforts. The SES is particularly concerned about the Hunter Region, which was severely affected by last week's storm. The forecast predicts varying weather conditions across different parts of New South Wales, with Sydney expected to experience showers and a chance of late showers, while Newcastle and surrounding areas are predicted to have showers and possible late showers. The Bureau of Meteorology suggests that the main impacts of intense rainfall and strong winds will be on coastal areas in the state's northeast, including the Northern Rivers and Mid North Coast, with heavy falls also likely for southeast Queensland. The SES will continue its clean-up efforts and warn residents to prepare their homes for potential severe weather.

Nina Moric, a model known for her appearance in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, has denied attempting suicide. She clarified that she was hospitalized due to low blood pressure and a domestic accident, not a suicide attempt. Italian media had reported that she tried to take her own life and was found by her mother, but Moric's account contradicts these claims. She mentioned that her boyfriend was not present at the time of the incident and that she is recovering at home. Additionally, there were past reports of Moric attempting suicide in 2009 after an overdose, but she has not commented on these claims in her recent post. Moric was once married to the notorious paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs.

The British public is hoping that the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge will name their second child Diana if it is a girl, as revealed by a YouGov survey for the Sunday Times. The name Diana, in honor of William's late mother, the Princess of Wales, is the top choice with 12% of the vote. Alice and Charlotte are the next most popular options, each receiving 9%. If the baby is a boy, James and Alexander are the favored names, with James leading at 13%. Many Brits are hoping for a girl, with a quarter of those polled expressing this preference. The poll also showed strong support for William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber detonated near a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding dozens, including an Afghan lawmaker. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other group has claimed it. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time in the city of Khost, where protesters were on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor.

Dani Alves, the Brazilian right-back, is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Despite having a successful seven-year tenure with the club, winning multiple Spanish titles and the Champions League twice, Alves could not come to terms with Barcelona on a new deal. His agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed at a press conference that Alves turned down a three-year contract offer that was contingent on him playing in 60 percent of the matches. The negotiations have ended, and Alves will leave the Nou Camp this summer.

Pablo Osvaldo, a player at Boca Juniors, has suggested that Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti should join him at the club, believing their style and skills would be perfect for Boca and would be greatly appreciated by the fans.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, suffered a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton. Despite the dramatic fall, which has been widely viewed online, Ferguson sustained only a cut on his nose. He was back at work at Paul Nicholls' yard the next day, mucking out stables as usual, and remains undeterred from getting back in the saddle. His fellow jockeys, who watched the fall with him, expressed concern and support. Ferguson joked about possibly pursuing a career in gymnastics due to the impressive nature of his fall.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, dressed as Iron Man from the movie "Avengers: Age of Ultron" and shared the photo on Instagram. The movie premiered at Westfield London with stars like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell played for Wasps from 2002 to 2009, then had stints at Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders before returning to Wasps in 2012. Since his return, he has made over 100 appearances for the club and has 57 England caps.

The wide leg trouser is a prominent trend for SS15, offering an alternative to the ubiquitous skinny jean. The style, reminiscent of the 70s, provides an effortless and refreshing look. Key to pulling off the wide leg is pairing it with a high-heeled shoe and keeping the top half of the outfit simple. Denim is the easiest way to achieve this trend, with brands like Gucci and Topshop offering versions. Celine and Stella McCartney have also incorporated the look into their collections with more dressy styles. The wide leg trouser is versatile and suitable for various occasions, including evening wear, and can be found at various price points. Poppy Delevingne has also showcased this trend on the runway.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite a petition from students who objected to its portrayal of the Iraq War and its impact on Middle Eastern people. The decision to cancel the screening was reversed due to backlash and a counter-petition, emphasizing the university's commitment to freedom of expression. The university will also offer an alternative screening of "Paddington" for those who prefer not to watch "American Sniper."

On April 3, two French tourists on Rottnest Island, near Perth, Western Australia, allegedly set a quokka on fire by igniting an aerosol spray with a lighter. The quokka, a cat-sized marsupial native to Australia, was singed but survived the incident. The tourists, aged 18 and 24 and residing in Cockburn Central, were questioned by detectives, had video evidence seized, and were charged with animal cruelty. They were subsequently evicted from the island and are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas are typically found on small islands off the west coast of Australia, including Rottnest and Bald Island near Albany.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer from the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen herself dance until filmmakers and volunteers compiled early music videos, known as "soundies," of her performances. She expressed delight upon viewing the videos, which included her dancing alongside notable figures like Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. The footage helped her relive her past and see herself dance for the first time.

The art of washing one's own car is declining in Britain, with a third of men admitting they've never done it. Women are more likely to take their cars to a car wash. Reasons for this decline include the rise of hand car washes, larger vehicles being harder to clean, and changing Sunday routines due to more shops being open and more live football on TV. The tradition of washing cars on Sundays is fading, with Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield having the highest rates of car washing by owners, and Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh having the lowest. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners are most likely to wash their own cars, while Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners do so least often.

The passage discusses Martin Skrtel's admiration for Steven Gerrard, Liverpool's captain, who is set to play his final game for the club in the FA Cup final on his birthday, May 30. Skrtel, who joined Liverpool in 2008, credits Gerrard with helping him settle into the team and views him as one of the best players in the world. He acknowledges that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard but believes the club has players who can fill his void if given the right support. Both Skrtel and Gerrard are available to play against Aston Villa in the FA Cup semi-final after serving three-match bans.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75 years old, made a hole in one during the Par-3 contest at Augusta National, his first ace on the course. He was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw when he achieved this feat, which was one of five hole-in-ones on the day, tying the record set in 2002. Although Camilo Villegas also made two aces, including one on the same hole as Nicklaus, Kevin Streelman won the contest in a playoff. Nicklaus, who won his first green jacket at 23 and his sixth in 1986, is one of five golfers to have completed the career Grand Slam. Rory McIlroy has a chance to join this elite group if he wins his third consecutive major.

Tornado warnings were issued in Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night, with reports of twisters near Goddard, Kansas, and Potosi, Missouri. Storms were expected to continue into Thursday, affecting the midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and southern Great Lakes regions. Nighttime tornadoes are considered the most dangerous.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris during an arrest. Bates claims the shooting was accidental, intending to use a Taser but mistakenly using a gun. The family of Eric Harris criticized Bates for planning a vacation to the Bahamas during this time, perceiving it as apathetic. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. His defense team anticipates dealing with the facts in court rather than through media. The Harris family's lawyer alleges that Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff, a claim the sheriff's office denies. Training documents released by Bates' lawyer suggest he had proper law enforcement training. Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing to challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11. He has a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach with the caption "if you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor believes he has more motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it for the eighth time. The fighters have a contentious relationship, highlighted by an incident during a promotional tour in Dublin where McGregor took Aldo's belt from him in front of 5,000 fans.

Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a beer at an Australian rules function, drawing criticism from anti-drinking campaigners who argue he is glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with alcohol consumption. Cultural studies professor Julie Roberts from the University of Technology Sydney finds it problematic that Abbott, who should be advocating against binge drinking, instead showcases his masculinity by quickly consuming alcohol. Roberts highlights that such actions can lead to people forgetting their limits and emphasizes that drinking should be about socializing rather than a competition of quantity and speed. Despite the criticism, Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, suggesting that his early morning exercise routine demonstrates his commitment to fitness. The incident has sparked a debate about the role of leaders in setting examples for responsible drinking behavior, with critics arguing that Abbott should not equate heavy drinking with being a "true blue Aussie bloke."

Governor Mike Pence of Indiana approved a 30-day needle exchange program in response to a significant increase in HIV cases in Scott County, which has seen 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positives linked to opioid use, particularly the painkiller Opana. The program, which began March 26, has distributed 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected 1,400 used syringes. Health officials expect the number of cases to rise as more people are tested. The future of the program and legislation allowing needle exchanges in other counties is uncertain, as Pence and some lawmakers express concerns that needle exchanges could promote drug use. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention notes a high correlation between hepatitis C and HIV infections, suggesting that high hepatitis C rates indicate potential HIV outbreaks. The House has passed a bill allowing needle exchanges in counties with high hepatitis C rates, but its fate and the continuation of the Scott County program are unclear as Pence and lawmakers consider the balance between public health and anti-drug policy.

summary: a woman named saskia took a test on arsenal football club created by her boyfriend, scoring 43.5 out of 50. despite some mistakes, like confusing player positions and getting an answer wrong, she impressed him enough to avoid being dumped. her boyfriend's test included questions about arsenal's history, current players, and opinions on rival teams. saskia's creative answers, such as calling eden hazard a "p***k," earned her extra points. the boyfriend's strict grading and angry faces when she got answers wrong showed his passion for the club. comments on social media hailed the boyfriend as a "legend" and praised saskia as "proper gf material," while others thought the boyfriend took things too far.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellin cartel member, worked undercover for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for U.S. citizenship. Despite his significant contributions to the agency, including helping to take down major figures like Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega, Toro has not received citizenship and is now facing deportation. Toro fears for his life if returned to Colombia and is struggling with health issues and financial instability. The DEA has not provided the promised citizenship, and Toro is currently living in the U.S. illegally. He is seeking a green card or passport and is prepared to go into hiding if necessary.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village. She is now in a Delhi hospital with 70% burns. The attack occurred on Sunday when she went outside her house to relieve herself. Her brother found her on fire and doused her with water. The accused men have been arrested. The incident comes amid heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following the ban on the documentary "India's Daughter" about the 2012 gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh. The documentary highlighted the brutal attack on a student returning from the cinema, leading to widespread protests and calls for better protection for women. Recent incidents in India, including a mob beating a man to death for allegedly raping and killing an 11-year-old girl, have shown the public's anger and the demand for justice.

Louis van Gaal, the manager of Manchester United, has expressed his desire to win the derby against Manchester City on Sunday, despite acknowledging that Robin van Persie will not be fit to play. Van Gaal has set high expectations for his team, aiming for a top three finish in the league to secure a spot in the Champions League group stage without the need for a qualifying round. He emphasized the importance of controlling aggression and learning from their previous loss to City. Additionally, Van Gaal confirmed that Luke Shaw is not yet fit enough to play. The manager is looking forward to experiencing the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford with home advantage for the first time since his arrival at the club.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against rising ticket prices at the Emirates Stadium, leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their match. The protest was in response to the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal and high ticket prices, with the cheapest tickets starting at £64. Fans from both clubs held banners inside and outside the stadium, expressing their discontent with the cost of following their teams. The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups. They called for tangible reductions in ticket prices to reflect working-class earnings, fearing the loss of a generation of fans if the footballing authorities do not address the issue. Further protests are expected after the match.

A newborn baby named Star was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, shortly after birth. Her parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, were informed that she would need a liver transplant to survive. Neither parent was a suitable match for the transplant. Star's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, who is Jade's twin sister, offered to donate part of her liver. Shanell underwent the surgery and successfully donated a portion of her liver to Star, saving her life. Star underwent the transplant in November and has since made a good recovery. Shanell also recovered well from the surgery and stated that she did not hesitate to donate part of her liver to save her niece.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake won the Audi Football Challenge against teammates Loic Remy and Willian. The challenge included shooting balls into car boots, playing football over a car acting as a net, and shooting from long range to sink balls into convertibles. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, while Remy and Willian won the final round by damaging a wing mirror on one of the Audis with a long-range shot, though they won't have to pay for the repair.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, caused a fatal highway crash in December 2013 when he drove his truck across a median at over 100mph and collided with an oncoming SUV. The crash killed 24-year-old Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé Jason Timmons. Dellinger, 54, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide in the deaths of the couple and to one count of assault for the fetus' death. He faces 12 to 24 years in prison. During his sentencing, Dellinger stated that he was not suicidal at the time of the crash. His wife, Deborah, testified to his character, describing him as a man of ethics and integrity who has lived his life with grace and modesty, despite serious health problems. The couple expressed their devastation and offered prayers for the victims' families. Dellinger's attorneys cited his withdrawal from Ambien, a psychiatric drug overdose, and prozac, as well as the advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis, as factors contributing to the crash. He had previously held high-level positions at several major corporations.

Lacey Spears, a woman from Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt. She was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed his anger on Facebook, hoping she would die in prison and criticizing her lack of emotion during the sentencing. The prosecutor, Janet Difiore, described the crime as "unfathomable in its cruelty" and blamed Spears for her son's short and tormented life. Spears, who lived in Chestnut Ridge, New York, was said to have used her son's illnesses for self-aggrandizement on social media. She did not testify at her trial.

The new influenza vaccine arriving in Australia includes protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the United States. The vaccine is expected to be more effective than the previous one and is arriving a month later than anticipated. High-risk groups will have access to free flu shots from April 20, and it is recommended that everyone gets vaccinated, as the modified vaccine also covers H1N1. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, emphasizes the importance of getting vaccinated to prevent deaths and protect vulnerable populations.

the passage discusses the state of abraham lincoln's tomb in springfield, illinois, which is facing criticism from a national geographic article and potential budget cuts. despite renovations, the tomb is described as having an office lobby-like appearance and is criticized for its incongruous art deco style. caretakers defend the site, noting recent repairs and renovations costing over $2.5 million. they express concern over looming budget cuts that could affect the tomb's management and public access. the anniversary of lincoln's assassination is mentioned, highlighting the significance of the site amidst these challenges.

The passage discusses several fashion trends from the nineties and noughties that are making a comeback or should be left in the past. These include:

1. The bucket hat, which was popular in the nineties and is now making a comeback with celebrities like Rihanna.
2. Camouflage print, which was favored by Destiny's Child and is still seen in the wardrobes of stars like Jourdan Dunn.
3. Taking trends to the extreme, exemplified by celebrities like Victoria Beckham and Justin Timberlake in the past and Kylie Jenner today.
4. Ugg boots, which were popular with celebrities like Paris Hilton and remain cozy choices for off-duty celebrities like Kristen Bell.
5. Daisy dukes, reintroduced by Jessica Simpson and still worn by Miley Cyrus in a more provocative manner.
6. Juicy Couture tracksuits, which were popular with celebrities like Nicole Richie and Paris Hilton and are still favored by Nicki Minaj.
7. Colored sunglasses, which were popular with boy bands and pop stars in the nineties and are now worn by Cara Delevingne and Kylie Jenner.
8. Corsets as outerwear, popularized by Victoria Beckham and now

This week, four rainbows appeared in the sky over the New York area after heavy rain. In China, there has been a crackdown on exotic dancers performing at wakes, as this practice is becoming increasingly common. Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during an interview when asked about his private life. The Kardashians have started a new trend with the #kyliejennerchallenge, which involves sucking on a jar to plump lips. A 102-year-old woman, Alice Barker, went back in time with the help of filmmakers for a prom-posal that referenced bombs, leading to accusations of racism against the school. Ewan McGregor is set to play Lumiere in the new 'Beauty and the Beast' film, and Johnny Depp's transformation in 'Black Mass' has been noted. A couple announced their pregnancy by referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', and a military dad photobombed his son, showcasing originality.

Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory at the Miami Open with a giant cake. Andy Murray previously received a cake for his 500th win. Serena advanced to the semi-finals by defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets. In the quarter-finals, Serena beat Lisicki, avenging a Wimbledon 2013 loss. Serena will face Simona Halep in the semi-finals after Halep defeated Sloane Stephens.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance, was killed by gunmen in Karachi. She was known for her Second Floor cafe, which hosted discussions on various topics including human rights and women's entrepreneurship. Mahmud had just finished leading a discussion on the sensitive topic of Balochistan's insurgency when she was shot. Despite receiving death threats in the past, she continued to speak out on issues that many in Pakistan are too afraid to address. Her death has sparked grief and gratitude for her work among those who valued her efforts to promote free speech and secular wisdom.

The passage discusses the plight of Hindu refugees, known as West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), who fled to India's Jammu region during the partition of India in 1947. Despite being born in India and living there for multiple generations, these refugees have been denied basic citizenship rights such as owning property, voting in state elections, and working for the state government. The denial of these rights has kept them in abject poverty. The situation has persisted due to fears from the state government of upsetting the demographic balance between Hindus and Muslims in India's only Muslim-majority state, Jammu and Kashmir. However, with the recent election success of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in the state, there is hope for change. The BJP is expected to champion the cause of the WPRs, potentially leading to the granting of citizenship rights and an improvement in their living conditions. The passage also mentions ongoing unrest in Kashmir due to various factions fighting for independence or merger with Pakistan, despite the region being one of India's more prosperous states.

Yoshinori Muto, an FC Tokyo forward, is considering joining Premier League leaders Chelsea this summer. Chelsea has reportedly made an offer around £4million for the 22-year-old, with plans to loan him to Vitesse Arnhem. Muto is contemplating a move where he can play regularly and develop. Ranko Popovic, his former coach, praised Muto's intelligence, speed, strength, and confidence, noting his unique qualities and potential. Chelsea manager José Mourinho acknowledged Muto's talent but declined to comment further, citing respect for FC Tokyo. The potential transfer is influenced by Chelsea's commercial interests with Japanese sponsor Yokohama Rubber and the need to adhere to financial fair play rules.

The passage discusses the outdated policy of the English Rugby Football Union (RFU) and Premier Rugby not selecting their best players if they are playing overseas. It praises Australia for dropping such a policy and highlights the examples of Matt Giteau, Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon, and Jonny Wilkinson, who have improved their performances by playing overseas. The passage argues that England's coach, Stuart Lancaster, should be free to pick his best players regardless of their location, emphasizing the importance of fielding the strongest possible team for the World Cup. It concludes by criticizing the English approach as potentially detrimental to the team's success and calls for a change in policy to avoid 'what ifs' during the tournament.

Open Garden has developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped device designed to enhance the performance of wireless mesh networks. Greenstone acts as a beacon or booster for messages within these networks, which are created by the Firechat app. Firechat, which has been downloaded over five million times, allows users to chat without the need for the web or mobile signal by creating a local network where each phone becomes a node for data transmission. Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) introduced in iOS 7 facilitates this feature, enabling Bluetooth and Wi-Fi Direct connections for message exchange up to around 30 feet (9 meters). Greenstone extends the range of these networks to approximately 20 feet (6 meters) and is designed to improve communication resilience in areas without connectivity. It holds up to 1,000 recent messages and has a one-year battery life. Open Garden is working with manufacturers to bring Greenstone to market.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, gave a TED talk where she discussed reclaiming the word 'fat' as a positive descriptor of her body. She emphasized that 'fat' should not be synonymous with 'ugly' and highlighted the societal pressure on women to be thin. Bustle shared that size discrimination in the workplace has increased by 66% in the last 30 years, and young girls often wish to be thinner. However, she cited studies showing that exposure to diverse body types increases tolerance and preference for different body shapes. Performing burlesque allows Bustle to present a 'fat' body in a positive and glamorous light, challenging societal beauty norms. She recalls her first performance as empowering and recommends finding a 'courage reference' to boost self-esteem. Despite some negative comments, the response to her TED talk has been overwhelmingly positive, with viewers expressing gratitude and sharing personal stories of body acceptance. Bustle believes that the movement towards body positivity is gaining momentum.

Theo Walcott has been on the bench for most of Arsenal's games this season. He was part of a Lanvin photoshoot with Arsenal teammates and model Olga Sherer. The team will wear Lanvin attire for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott hopes to start against Hull on Monday after coming off the bench in the recent Chelsea match.

The collection of props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker, including iconic items from films like "Men in Black," "Batman Forever," and "How the Grinch Stole Christmas," will be auctioned off in May. The collection, estimated to be worth $746,100, features high-value items such as the Alien Edgar Bug from "Men in Black" valued at $40,000, the Two-Face mask from "Batman Forever" at $1,500, and the Grinch costume from "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" at $8,000. The auction will take place at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and online through propstore.com on May 29. The items come from over 50 productions spanning Baker's 30-year career, including works like "An American Werewolf in London," "Planet of the Apes," and "Mighty Joe Young." The sale offers a unique opportunity for fans and collectors to own a piece of Hollywood history.

Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old British boy, died in the French Alps after becoming separated from his mother and falling over a 164ft drop while trying to find his way back to the resort. His family described him as a lively, outgoing, and determined child who brought joy to their lives. Despite being a very competent skier and snowboarder who started skiing at the age of three, Carwyn wandered off the piste into dense woodland, likely trying to reach the resort he could see below. His mother, believing he had returned to the hotel, only realized he was missing when he did not come back. Police found Carwyn's body following footprints in the snow, which showed his final steps were broken up by sliding marks as he tried to navigate the steeper inclines on his backside. The family is devastated, stating that his death has left a vast void in their hearts. Carwyn's friends and community back in Wales are mourning his loss, with tributes expressing their grief and fond memories of the young boy.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia due to pressures to be thin and fit into societal expectations of a "size zero." She became obsessed with her weight, hiding food, and eating as little as one piece of fruit a day. Her health deteriorated to the point of collapsing at home, leading to a week on a heart monitor in intensive care. Laura's story highlights the dangers of extreme dieting and the importance of addressing the societal pressures on young girls to achieve an unrealistic body image. She has since recovered and is participating in Miss Teen GB, a contest that promotes positive body image and self-confidence.

raheem sterling and other liverpool players unveiled the club's new home kit designed by new balance at anfield on friday. the kit features an all-white branding with a gingham design and a memorial flame for the hillsborough disaster. fans urged sterling to stay at the club, to which he responded positively about the support. liverpool is confident sterling will remain despite his recent contract rejection and comments about being flattered by interest from arsenal. the team is focused on winning the fa cup, with sterling highlighting the significance of playing at wembley, his home town.

a high-definition map of dark matter has been created by researchers at the university of manchester, showing clumps of the mysterious substance across 0.4% of the sky. the map is part of the dark energy survey (des), which aims to eventually map 12.5% of the sky in 3d, allowing astronomers to study galaxy formation. dark matter, which makes up 80% of the universe's matter, cannot be directly observed but its gravitational effects can be measured. the map was made by analyzing the shapes of galaxies and will help test current theories about the relationship between dark matter and galaxy formation.

manchester united have made an official approach to sign psv eindhoven 's 21-year-old winger memphis depay .
the dutch international was part of louis van gaal 's 2014 world cup squad and scored in the tournament .
psv technical director marcel brands confirmed united 's interest , saying they are competing with big european clubs including paris saint-germain for depay 's signature .
depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season and has been linked with moves to tottenham and other clubs in the past .
born in 1994 , depay started his career at vv moordrecht and joined psv at the age of 12 .
he has made over 100 appearances for the club and has been tipped to become as good as arjen robben by psv manager phillip cocu .
former manchester united scout ed van steijn believes depay could one day rival cristiano ronaldo .
depay has also been capped by holland at international level and scored in the 2014 world cup .

chelsea took a 3-1 lead against manchester city 's youth side in the youth cup final first leg at the academy stadium . tammy abraham scored twice with volleys, and dominic solanke added a third goal late on. manchester city 's kean bryan missed a chance to level the score, while isaac buckley-ricketts scored the city goal. key players for chelsea included tammy abraham, who was later substituted due to injury, and dominic solanke, who scored the decisive goal. for manchester city, kean bryan and isaac buckley-ricketts were notable contributors.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, believes that people are born with a sexual preference but does not think same-sex marriage should be a constitutional right. He argues that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman and that states should decide on the issue through their legislatures, not the courts. Despite his stance against same-sex marriage, he has stated that he would attend the wedding of a family member or staff member involved in a same-sex union out of respect for their relationship. He also mentioned that as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong, but it would not affect his love for someone who was divorced.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple from the UK and Latvia who embarked on a global cycling adventure after quitting their jobs. They have no fixed plans, agenda, or cause, and their primary goal is to explore the world at a leisurely pace. Since starting their journey, they have covered nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, averaging less than 3 euros per person per day. They rely on free accommodation, such as camping, using hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and accepting the kindness of strangers. Their main expenses are for food, which they keep minimal by eating simple, affordable meals and sometimes accepting meals from hosts. They started their journey in London and have since cycled through France, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and Turkey, with plans to continue into Asia and eventually cycle through the Americas. Their lifestyle is minimalist, focusing on the journey and the experiences rather than on material possessions or a strict schedule.

In 2012, a Texas couple hired a photographer named James Evans from Premiere Photos for their wedding. After the event, the bride's sister discovered that the photo booth operated by Premiere Photos had printed offensive racial slurs on the bottom of some of the photographs. The slurs were reportedly "Poor N***** Party." The couple, who wishes to remain anonymous, is represented by attorney Cathy Hale and is suing Premiere Photos for negligence and breach of contract under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act. James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, denies the allegations and reportedly told the couple to "sue" him when confronted. The couple is seeking an apology at minimum and is scheduled for mediation in July if an agreement cannot be reached beforehand.

Mike Brown, the England full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recover from his latest concussion. He withdrew from Harlequins' match against Saracens at Wembley due to the lingering effects of a concussion sustained after the game against France. Brown is determined not to rush back into action, learning from the experiences of other players like George North and Johnny Sexton who have suffered multiple concussions. He emphasizes the importance of being aware of concussion symptoms and the necessity of not playing through them, a lesson he learned from World Rugby's online modules. Brown aims to return to action gradually, starting with a 20-minute bike ride to assess his recovery. He acknowledges that while missing big games like England-Ireland can be tough, prioritizing health over rugby is crucial.

The frequency of sex among Britons has reportedly declined since the emergence of the internet, with heterosexual couples now having sex three times a month on average, compared to five times a month in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, suggests that the decline may be due to the increased integration of public and private lives, leading to less 'quiet empty time' and more time spent checking emails. The busier lives and constant connectivity have pushed sex down the list of priorities for many couples.

Tibetan mastiffs, once highly sought after and fetching prices up to £1.2 million, have plummeted in popularity in China due to the country's anti-corruption campaign and new regulations limiting the ownership of large dogs. The crackdown on corruption has led to a decline in the gifting of these dogs to officials, and the ban on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities has further reduced their appeal. As a result, many Tibetan mastiffs are now being sent to slaughterhouses, where their meat is used in cheap hotpots and their skin for leather belts. Animal welfare groups have rescued some dogs destined for slaughter, highlighting the cruel fate of these once-prized animals. The situation has also led to an increase in theft of the dogs by gangs and the offloading of 'imperfect' specimens by breeders to abattoirs. The decline in the breed's quality due to profit-driven cross-breeding has exacerbated the problem. The combination of urbanization and changing attitudes towards large dogs as unsuitable for city living has contributed to the Tibetan mastiff's fall from grace.

A survey conducted in Paris found that every woman surveyed claimed to have experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half of them experiencing it before the age of 18. The poll highlighted that such harassment, ranging from insults to sexual assault, is pervasive and often goes unreported, leading to fear among women and limiting their freedom to use public spaces. The findings prompted calls for a campaign to address and reduce sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains, emphasizing the need for women to recognize and report harassment as a criminal act punishable by law.

Direct Line, a UK-based company, is running a competition called #everydayfix to turn a winning prototype into a real product. The competition was part of a design makeathon where groups were tasked with creating products to solve common everyday problems. The top three finalists are:

1. **Forget Me Lock**: A device that attaches to your key and changes color to indicate whether your door is locked or open. This helps alleviate the stress of forgetting if you've locked your door.

2. **Snooze**: An alarm clock that connects to your phone and silences notifications to ensure a good night's sleep. This addresses the issue of being woken up by phone notifications.

3. **Nipper**: A tiny mobile phone charger that uses household batteries as a power source. It's designed for people who run out of battery while out and about.

Participants can vote for their favorite product on Twitter using the #everydayfix hashtag. The product with the most retweets by April 46 will go into a Kickstarter campaign to fund its development. The competition highlighted various other innovative ideas that didn't make the final shortlist, including a parking pin to alert you when a parking space is available and

Police and Crime Commissioner Vera Baird awarded £500,000 of taxpayer money to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she directs, alongside Northumbria Police Chief Constable Sue Sim. The allocation of funds has sparked a Ministry of Justice investigation due to concerns of conflict of interest and inappropriate use of public money. Critics, including Keith Vaz, have described the situation as a "soap opera" within the force and have questioned the appropriateness of a PCC funding an organization in which they have a personal interest. Vera Baird defends the decision, stating that all procedures and protocols were followed. Sue Sim, who gained notoriety for her handling of the Raoul Moat manhunt, is retiring from the force in June. The Ministry of Justice will investigate to determine if any conflict of interest rules were violated.

Three people have been jailed and two are awaiting sentencing for their roles in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man. The ringleader, Corey Campbell, 21, believed the victim, Greg Valecce, had hurt his cat, Pebbles. Valecce was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos. The incident occurred in late March 2014 in the basement of a house in Mayfair, Philadelphia. Valecce suffered multiple injuries and was held for about 42 hours. Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, and Carl Halin, 18, were charged with aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment. They all pleaded guilty. Campbell was sentenced to 20 years in state prison, Halin received the same sentence, and Ng was sentenced to 23 months. David Thomas, 28, is awaiting sentencing, and Jennifer Pratt, 40, is awaiting trial. Valecce has had the tattoos removed and says the incident has left him with irreparable damage, including fear to go outside and nightmares.
